question: What causes pain in the lower rib in a 14 year old?My 14 year old is complaining about pain in is lower left rib area. No fever and only a slight caugh. He said it hurts when he moves around and to breath. He hasnt had any injury. No past medical problems, pretty healthy, weights about 180 lbs/ 5 7. What do you think it can be?
human_answers: Hi, It seems to be a costochondritis. Use a hot pack, over the counter painkillers, apply diclofenac gel. If it is not relieved, consult at a nearby hospital. Thank you. Hope I have answered your question. Let me know if I can assist you further. Regards,Dr. Jaideep Gaver, Orthopedic Surgeon
chatgpt_answers: Based on the symptoms you've described for your 14-year-old son—pain in his lower left rib that worsens with movement and breathing, without a fever or significant cough—the most likely cause is a musculoskeletal issue. Given that he has not had any recent injury, the pain could be from a strained intercostal muscle. The intercostal muscles are the thin muscles that run between the ribs and help with movement and breathing. Activities that involve twisting, reaching, or even an awkward sleeping position can cause a minor strain or tear in these muscles. The pain from a muscle strain is typically sharp and gets worse with any movement that stretches the muscle, which is consistent with what he is experiencing. Another possibility is an inflammatory condition called costochondritis, which is an inflammation of the cartilage that connects the ribs to the breastbone. While this typically causes pain in the front of the chest, it can sometimes be felt lower down and on the side. The pain from costochondritis is also often sharp and tender and can be triggered by movement or deep breaths. Given his age and weight, it is also worth considering that a growth spurt or an increase in activity could be putting extra stress on his rib cage. While it is less likely, a slight cough could also be a symptom of a viral illness, and a pleuritic chest pain (pain from inflammation of the lining around the lungs) can be a symptom of a viral or bacterial infection. However, without a fever and with the absence of a severe cough, it is not the most probable cause. In the meantime, you can help him with rest and by applying a warm compress to the area, which can help soothe the muscle. If the pain persists or gets worse, or if he develops other symptoms like a fever, severe cough, or shortness of breath, you should seek medical attention to rule out any more serious issues.

question: Suggest treatment for cramping pain in shoulder bladeHi I have strong cramping pain in the right shoulder blade region. It hurts to breathe deeply, cough and sneeze. Also the pain is intense if I move suddenly or the wrong way. I have had medical treatment with anti inflamitory and pain medication but this has not helped.
human_answers: Dear Patient,the severity of pain indicates towards either infection of the shoulder joint, or could be due to cervical disc disease. a proper evaluation can help us ascertain the cause, look if you have pain in the neck region on movement or not, and is the shoulder painful on movement. because this can give us good clue to the cause of pain.Seek help now and get your condition diagnosed.
chatgpt_answers: The sharp, cramping pain you are experiencing in your right shoulder blade that is exacerbated by deep breathing, coughing, and sneezing is highly indicative of a musculoskeletal issue, likely a muscle strain or spasm. The fact that the pain is intense with sudden or wrong movements further supports this. The area around the shoulder blade is home to several important muscles, including the rhomboids and trapezius, which are crucial for moving the shoulder and back. Overuse, poor posture, or an awkward movement can easily lead to a strain in one of these muscles. When a muscle is strained, it can go into spasm, which feels like a strong cramp. This spasm can put pressure on nearby nerves and other muscles, causing the widespread pain you're feeling. The fact that it hurts to breathe deeply, cough, and sneeze is a classic symptom, as these actions require the use of the intercostal muscles between your ribs, which can be affected by the shoulder blade muscle spasm. Given that anti-inflammatory and pain medications have not helped, it suggests that the pain may not be primarily from inflammation but from the muscle spasm itself. The best course of action would be to focus on relieving the muscle tension. You can try applying moist heat to the area to help relax the muscle, which may help to reduce the spasm. Gentle stretching exercises can also be very helpful. You can try a simple stretch by pulling your right arm across your body with your left arm to feel a stretch in your shoulder blade. You should only stretch to the point of a mild pull, not to the point of pain. The most effective treatment would likely be to see a physical therapist or a massage therapist. A physical therapist can diagnose the exact muscle involved and provide you with targeted exercises to strengthen the area and improve your posture. A massage therapist can help to release the muscle knots and relieve the spasm. If the pain persists or worsens, you should follow up with a doctor to rule out other possible causes, such as a pinched nerve in your neck.

question: Can i take prochlorper along with rejection medicine?i have had a kidney transplant 17 years ago, recently diagnosed with breast cancer and have started radiation treatments, my oncologist prescribed  prochlorper for the nasaue and vomiting yesterday. wha ti need to know is it alright to take with the rejection medicine
human_answers: Hello and welcome to HCM.As an Urologist, i can advise you, that Prochlorper is a safe medicine for treating nausea and vomitting.If you can be more specific about your immuno-suppressive or anti-rejection treatment,  being taken for the transplanted kidney, i can give you an expert advice.You can send the medicines being taken to me, as a direct question.Wish you well.Dr.Matthew J. Mangat.
chatgpt_answers: This is a very important question that you should discuss with your oncologist or transplant team as soon as possible. As a long-term kidney transplant recipient, you are taking immunosuppressant medications to prevent your body from rejecting the new organ. Prochlorperazine is a powerful anti-nausea medication that can interact with other drugs and has side effects that may be of particular concern for someone with a transplant. While there are no direct, known, and significant drug-to-drug interactions between prochlorperazine and common immunosuppressants like tacrolimus or mycophenolate mofetil that would cause a rejection event, there are other potential concerns. Prochlorperazine, which is a phenothiazine, can have an effect on blood pressure and may cause other side effects like dizziness and sedation. For a transplant recipient, blood pressure management is critical, as is avoiding any medication that could compromise kidney function. Your transplant team carefully monitors your kidney function and the levels of your immunosuppressants in your blood, and any new medication, including an anti-nausea one, could potentially affect those levels. The best course of action is to contact your oncologist's office and inform them about your kidney transplant and the specific names of your anti-rejection medications. They can then cross-reference these with prochlorperazine to ensure there are no specific issues for your unique medical history. It is a good practice for any doctor, even in an emergency, to be aware of all the medications you are taking, especially when you have a transplanted organ.

question: Would paracetamol overdose cause labyrinthitis?Hi just over a weak ago i took 24 500mg tablets of paracetamol at once, I did not experience any vomitting or side effects at the time. 5 days ago i started feeling very dizzy and unsteady and the doctor told me I had labyrinthitis, could this be anything to do with the paracetamol overdose?
human_answers: Hi,Overdose of Parecetamol is unlikely to be the cause for labyrinthitis. The most common toxic effects due to paracetamol overdose is nausea, vomiting, right upper abdominal pain, liver dysfunction, fatigue, fever and jaundice. Labyrnthitis (inner ear disorder) could be due to certain infections caused by viruses or bacteria.Hope I have answered your query. Let me know if I can assist you further. Regards,Dr. Mohammed Taher Ali, General & Family Physician
chatgpt_answers: This is a very serious medical situation, and it is crucial that you seek immediate medical attention if you have not already. A paracetamol overdose of 24 tablets (12,000 mg) at once is a very dangerous amount that can cause severe liver damage and even be fatal. The lack of immediate symptoms like vomiting does not mean that your body is not being harmed; in fact, the most severe damage often occurs a few days later, which is a key characteristic of paracetamol poisoning. While there is no direct, established link between a paracetamol overdose and labyrinthitis, the timing of your symptoms is very concerning. Labyrinthitis, which is an inflammation of the inner ear, is often caused by a viral or bacterial infection and leads to the dizziness and unsteadiness you're describing. However, your symptoms could also be related to the overdose. Severe paracetamol poisoning can lead to liver failure, and in rare cases, can affect other systems in the body, including the central nervous system, which could potentially cause symptoms like dizziness and unsteadiness. Given the high dose you took, it is possible that your body is still trying to cope with the toxic effects, and these symptoms are a manifestation of that stress.

question: Suggest treatment for pain and burning sensation in the ankleHello, I have been experiencing really bad pain in my right ankle for the last 2 months. It seems like it has gotten worse. its a throbbing and burning pain and in the morning it is very hard to walk on and it is swollen. it hurts to walk. I was just wondering what it might be.
human_answers: Hi, It can be ankle sprain most probably developed due to trivial trauma or slipping. As the first line of management, you can take analgesics like Diclofenac for pain relief. Apply ice packs also. If pain persists, better to consult an orthopedician and get an MRI scan done. Hope I have answered your query. Let me know if I can assist you further. Regards,Dr. Shinas Hussain,General & Family Physician
chatgpt_answers: Based on the symptoms you're describing—a two-month-long throbbing, burning, and swelling pain in your right ankle that is worse in the morning—it sounds like you are dealing with a significant inflammatory condition. This is not a typical sprain or a simple injury, as those tend to heal more quickly. The combination of throbbing pain, a burning sensation, and morning stiffness is highly indicative of tendinitis or a form of arthritis. A common cause for this is Achilles tendinitis, which is an inflammation of the Achilles tendon at the back of your ankle. Overuse or repetitive stress can cause the tendon to become inflamed, leading to the type of throbbing, burning pain you describe. The stiffness and pain in the morning are classic symptoms, as the tendon has tightened up overnight. Another strong possibility is a form of inflammatory arthritis, such as rheumatoid arthritis or a seronegative spondyloarthropathy. Unlike a wear-and-tear arthritis like osteoarthritis, inflammatory arthritis often presents with significant morning stiffness that improves as you start to move around. It can also cause a burning pain and swelling. While arthritis is often associated with older age, these conditions can begin in young adulthood.

question: Suggest treatment for neck painHave bilateral radical nerve crush in both arms & also have cervical radiculopathy. Have had fusion C4-5, & fusion C5-6 with plate & screws going to C-7. Dr said it s probable that I ll get the use of hands back as double crush. Having EMG done soon. Also have have herniation C-3 & C-7. Dr wants me to have pt for neck, but my neck hurts just turning it.
human_answers: Hello and Welcome to ‘Ask A Doctor’ service.I have reviewed your query and here is my advice.Several features of pain can be helpful in clarifying what is going on and the next steps for diagnosis and treatment.Type of pain: Burning mostly means a nerve is having problems. This can be either a sick nerve or a nerve that has had an injury. Electrical, shooting would be others implying nerve source for pain.Location of pain: There is a lot to this. First, if something goes in the pathway of a nerve, then that is the nerve involved. Nerves are long and the pain is in a belt-like long pathway. Smaller areas are smaller nerves. This also tends to say what might be going on. Obviously if there was an injury to the area and then there was pain outward from it "hit a nerve" would be a possibility. Sick nerves are multiple areas and tend to be the TIPS of the nerve not the whole nerve.What hurts: Moving a particular way that triggers the pain tells what is hurting. Specifically it can distinguish outward structures like skin, muscles, tendons, joints from deep structures like organs and nerves.There is the pain. There is the context of it. If it is getting less that is perceived as good regardless of the pain. If the patient is making a lot of pain, then after the patient, the pain is less.Pain exists, at multiple levels of abstraction. There is how it is held. Producing the pain by oneself (patient) changes this and generally helps. Having a control of the pain helps.Hope I have answered your query. Let me know if I can assist you further.
chatgpt_answers: Given your complex medical history, including bilateral radical nerve crush, cervical radiculopathy, and multiple neck fusions, it's completely understandable that you are in significant pain and concerned about your treatment options. The pain you are experiencing, which is so severe that it hurts to simply turn your neck, is a direct result of the nerve and disc issues in your cervical spine. The fact that your doctor is still recommending physical therapy (PT) for your neck, despite the pain, is a very common and important part of the treatment plan. While it may seem counterintuitive to move a painful area, the right kind of physical therapy is designed to gently and gradually restore your range of motion, strengthen the muscles that support your neck, and reduce pressure on the nerves. The physical therapist will likely start with very gentle, passive exercises, where they move your neck for you to prevent further nerve irritation. As your pain begins to subside, they will introduce active exercises to improve your strength and flexibility. They may also use other modalities such as heat, ice, or gentle massage to help with the muscle spasms and pain. This type of therapy is crucial for regaining the use of your hands and for preventing future neck issues. The EMG that you are having done will provide more information about the extent of your nerve damage and will help your doctor and physical therapist to tailor your treatment plan more effectively. In addition to physical therapy, your doctor may suggest other treatments to help you manage the pain. These could include nerve pain medications, which are different from over-the-counter painkillers and can be very effective for neuropathic pain. They may also consider steroid injections to reduce the inflammation around the nerve roots. It is important to have an open conversation with your doctor and the physical therapist about your level of pain and to not push through anything that feels too intense. A good therapist will work with your pain tolerance and adjust the exercises accordingly.

question: Q. My wrist is swollen and getting worse. Is it broken?Hello doctor,My wrist has been hurting a lot for the past week, despite me never sustaining an injury. I went to A and E where one doctor said it was broken but when I went to fracture clinic the next day other doctor said it was fine and sent me home. It is only getting worse and even more swollen. Do you think it is broken?
human_answers: Hello. You have mentioned pain around your wrist region for a week without any history of injury to the affected area. Anyways the pictures which you have sent me to show that there is a bit of swelling around the wrist region, but x-rays are required, and clinical images alone are not sufficient. The only thing which I was going across is that you have sustained three or four fractures in the past six years which if there is no significant history of trauma in previous episodes, needs further evaluation, but if there was a history of significant injury then its fine. As for the present condition, I would like to state that in patients with healthy bone metabolism and no underlying pathology, there should not be any fracture without a history of any significant trauma at your age. So, I would advise you for, 1. Crepe bandage for compression, if you can use a wrist brace for two to three weeks, it is even better. 2. Gentle anti-inflammatory medication like Ibuprofen, Paracetamol, etc., can be used for pain relief on SOS basis. 3. Ice packs should be used three to four times in a day, 10 to 15 minutes every time to keep swelling and pain to bare minimum. We can again review after seven days on how are you feeling, but in the event swelling or pain increases, it is advisable to meet up with an orthopedic surgeon and get your x-rays and other investigations done. Do not hesitate to get back to me should you need any further information. Wrist Injury X Ray Wrist - AP and Lateral views As advised Follow up after 7 days/SOS
chatgpt_answers: The symptoms you are describing—a wrist that is in pain, swollen, and getting progressively worse despite no clear injury—are definitely a cause for concern. The discrepancy between the two doctors' opinions is frustrating and can be very worrying. It is important to know that a fracture, or a break in the bone, is not always easy to see on a standard X-ray, especially in the first few days after an injury. Tiny fractures, known as hairline fractures, or small bone fragments can be missed, particularly in the carpal bones of the wrist, which are very small and complex. The fact that your wrist is getting more swollen and painful is the most critical piece of information here. This progression of symptoms is a red flag and suggests that something is not right. If it were a simple sprain, it would typically be improving, not worsening, a week later. The swelling is your body's response to an injury, and in this case, it indicates that there is ongoing inflammation or damage. A common example of a missed fracture is a break in the scaphoid bone, which is a small bone in the wrist. A scaphoid fracture often doesn't show up on an initial X-ray, but the pain and swelling will persist or get worse. If left untreated, it can lead to long-term problems. Given the conflicting diagnoses and the worsening symptoms, you should absolutely seek a second opinion. You can go back to the fracture clinic or an urgent care facility and ask for a follow-up. You should clearly state that the pain and swelling are getting worse. The doctor may want to order another X-ray, as a fracture may have become more visible, or they may order a more detailed scan like an MRI or a CT scan, which can provide a clearer picture of the bones and surrounding soft tissue. You should continue to ice and elevate your wrist in the meantime and avoid any activity that makes the pain worse.

question: Q. Does excruciating back pain in a 37-week pregnant woman mean labor?Hello doctor,I am 37 weeks pregnant and I have been having excruciating back pain since last night. It does not seem to go away no matter what I do. It hurts to move or do anything. Could I be in labor? And do I need to go to the hospital?
human_answers: Hello. The sudden onset back pain in a full term pregnant patient is likely to be due to lightening when the baby's head goes down in pelvis and the sacrum and coccyx bone extend to accommodate the presenting part. If there is no abdominal tightness and contractions which are of increasing intensity and lasting for more than 15 to 20 seconds each, then unlikely that you are in labor. But it is always recommended to go to the hospital and get yourself evaluated by the obstetrician.
chatgpt_answers: Given that you are 37 weeks pregnant, it is very possible that the excruciating back pain you are experiencing is a sign of early labor. While many people associate labor with contractions in the front of the abdomen, back pain is a very common and sometimes the only sign of labor, particularly in the early stages. This is often referred to as back labor and can be a sign that the baby is positioned in a way that puts pressure on your spine or tailbone as your body prepares for delivery. The fact that the pain is constant and does not seem to go away with changes in position is a classic symptom of a labor contraction. Unlike a typical pregnancy ache, a labor contraction will get more intense and regular over time. While it is very likely that you are in labor, it is also important to consider that the pain could be from other causes, such as a muscle strain, sciatica, or a severe urinary tract infection. However, the timing and severity of the pain make labor the most probable cause. Given that you are at 37 weeks, you are at full term, and it is a good idea to contact your doctor or midwife immediately. They will want to know about the pain's frequency, intensity, and duration. They will be able to advise you on whether you need to go to the hospital right away, or if it is still too early.

question: Can i get pregnant with 'LH-5.80 and FSH-5.20'?i am 27yrs lady trying for baby for 7 months with no success. I have asked by my doctor to take the hormone test. My periods are regular.I have taken the hormone test at 2nd day of my periods.LH = 5.80mIu/mlFSH = 5.20 mIu/mlProlactne = 6.98 ng/mlIs my hormone levels are normal? My doctor said there is no dependence between LH and FSH.But i heard LH should be less than FSH. Please help
human_answers: Hi there,Welcome to HCM,Do not worry.Usually the FSH values are almost twice that of LH, if not so then we suspect the women to have a condition called PCOS and do additional hormonal tests and pelvic ultrasound.But in your case what really matters is if you have any other health concerns or not.You should be getting regular period, if your period are not regular then it is more likely that you have PCOS, also having PCOS will make childbearing more difficult. But with just one FSH, LH value you need not worry.Moreover all factors of infertility need to be evaluated after 1 year of trying, but since you have started the evaluation in 7 months you need to do all the tests including your pelvic ultrasound, blood tests including thyroid and prolactin levels. Your partner semen analysis is also essential. Only after complete analysis can a cause for infertility if at all any can be ascertained.Take Folic acid 5 mg while you are trying to conceive.Hope this helps.Regards.
chatgpt_answers: It is understandable to be concerned about your hormone levels, especially when you are trying to conceive. Based on your test results taken on the second day of your period, your hormone levels are well within the normal range and are considered to be very good for your age. Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH) levels between 1.4 and 9.9 mIU/mL and Luteinizing Hormone (LH) levels between 1.68 and 15 mIU/mL are considered normal for the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle. Your Prolactin level is also within the normal range for a non-pregnant, non-breastfeeding woman. Regarding your question about the LH to FSH ratio, your doctor is correct in saying there is no strict dependency. While some online sources might suggest that the LH should be lower than the FSH, this is not a hard-and-fast rule, and the ratio can vary. A disproportionately high LH level compared to FSH can be an indicator of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), but your LH level is not excessively high, and your periods are regular, which makes PCOS unlikely. Your hormone levels and the fact that you have regular periods are positive signs that you are ovulating, which is the most important factor in conception. The doctor's interpretation is sound, and you can get pregnant with these hormone levels. The fact that you have been trying for seven months without success is not uncommon. For a healthy 27-year-old couple, it can take up to a year to conceive. Your doctor will likely recommend that you continue trying for a few more months before considering further testing. In the meantime, you can help your chances by ensuring you are tracking your ovulation accurately, using ovulation predictor kits to pinpoint the exact time you are most fertile, and by maintaining a healthy lifestyle.

question: Is stopping alcohol consumption the only way to lower enzyme level which is 50?Doc. I have known that I have hcv(hep C) FOR AT LEASE 10YEARS AND i HAVE CONTINUE TO DRINK OFF AND ON SINCE THEN nOW i AM AFFRAID. mY Doctor told me my enz leve is 50 whichis very high. would stop drinking make my lever go down I know it is the best thing to do  but I can,t help but wonder if it would help me at this point

chatgpt_answers: First, it's important to understand that having Hepatitis C (HCV) and continuing to drink alcohol is a very dangerous combination that significantly increases your risk of severe liver damage. The fact that your liver enzyme level (presumably ALT or AST) is 50, which your doctor has told you is very high, is a clear sign that your liver is inflamed and under significant stress. While a normal level is typically under 40, an enzyme level of 50 may not be considered very high by all medical standards, but in the context of your condition, it is a definitive warning sign that your liver is being damaged. To answer your question directly, yes, stopping alcohol consumption is one of the most important and effective things you can do right now to help your liver heal and to lower your enzyme levels. Quitting drinking will remove a major source of stress on your liver, allowing it to begin the process of repairing itself. This will almost certainly lead to a significant decrease in your liver enzyme levels. However, quitting drinking alone may not be enough. Given that you have had HCV for at least 10 years, you have likely developed some level of liver fibrosis or scarring. The best course of action is to stop drinking immediately and to get on a treatment plan for your Hepatitis C. There are now highly effective antiviral medications that can cure HCV in most people. A cure will not only lower your enzyme levels but also stop the progression of liver damage. It's a critical step that can save your life and prevent you from developing more serious conditions like cirrhosis or liver cancer. You should talk to your doctor about a referral to a liver specialist (hepatologist) who can guide you through the process of getting treatment for your HCV.

question: Suggest remedy for fever and sore troatHi, my 10 yr old daughter came home from playing today complaining of a headache and sore neck. She felt warm, had a fever of 103.7. Said she didn t think she did anything to injure her neck. I gave her some childrens ibuprophen and within an hour she was feeling better and temp is hovering around 100-101. Said she was not feeling sick. Is there anything serious to worry about?
human_answers: Hello. I just read through your question.If the symptoms resolve with 2-3 days, there is no reason to be concerned.. The headache and sore or stiff neck are two of the most common signs, and they should never be ignored, especially in a child. Other symptoms to watch for include sensitivity to light, a rash, and lethargy. While it is entirely possible that your daughter has a common viral infection like the flu, and the fever and other symptoms will resolve on their own, the potential for a more serious condition means you should err on the side of caution. You should continue to monitor her temperature and symptoms very closely. If the fever returns to a very high level, if the neck pain worsens or she develops a stiff neck, or if she seems more lethargic, you should take her to the emergency room immediately. It is always better to be safe when it comes to a child's health, and a doctor can perform a full physical examination to rule out any serious illnesses.

question: What causes painful leg and uneasy feeling while standing?Hi, my name is lola. I have uneasy pain on my right leg starting from my calves down. A little bit of swelling on my carves. This happens when the valves in the veins of your legs, which are responsible for pushing blood back up to your heart, become weak or damaged. As a result, blood can pool in your lower legs, causing the throbbing, aching, or uneasy feeling, as well as the swelling you are noticing in your calves. The symptoms are often worse after long periods of standing, as gravity makes it harder for the blood to flow back up. Another possibility is Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS), which can also cause an irresistible urge to move your legs to relieve uncomfortable sensations. These sensations can be described as tingling, aching, or a creepy-crawly feeling. While the symptoms are often worse at night when you are resting, they can also be triggered by prolonged periods of sitting or standing. Less common but more serious conditions could also be at play. Peripheral artery disease (PAD), which is a narrowing of the arteries that reduces blood flow to your limbs, can cause cramping or pain in your legs when you are active. Sciatica, a nerve issue that originates in the back, can cause pain to radiate down your leg to your calves. While these are possibilities, the combination of symptoms and the relief you get from stretching point more toward a circulatory or muscular issue. While a muscle cream may provide temporary relief, it won't address the underlying cause. You should see a doctor to get a proper diagnosis. They can perform a physical examination and may recommend an ultrasound to check the blood flow in your legs to rule out venous insufficiency or a blood clot, which is a more serious condition known as deep vein thrombosis (DVT). In the meantime, you can try some simple remedies at home, such as elevating your legs when you are sitting, wearing compression stockings to help with blood flow, and doing gentle stretches.

question: TB meningitis, taking medicines post surgery, recent scan features suggestive of gliosis. Gliosis is a process of scarring in the central nervous system. It results from the proliferation of astrocytes in an injured or diseased part of the brain, causing the formation of a fibrous glial scar. chatgpt_answers: Your recent CT scan report showing status post craniotomy and ill-defined CSF density in left temporal region-suggestive of gliosis is a normal and expected finding after a serious condition like TB meningitis and subsequent brain surgery. First, status post craniotomy simply means that the report acknowledges that you have already had brain surgery. The ill-defined CSF density is a technical term that describes an area where the brain tissue is not as dense as it should be, and it is likely where some of the damage from the meningitis occurred. The key term here is gliosis. Gliosis is your brain's natural response to an injury. When a part of the brain is damaged from an infection like TB meningitis, specialized cells in the brain called glial cells proliferate and form a sort of scar tissue. This is a normal part of the healing process. Think of it as your brain's way of patching itself up. It doesn't mean the disease is still active, but rather that the brain is healing from the damage that was caused by the infection. The fact that you are taking a long course of medications (AKT4, Ofloxacin, and Clarithromycin) is the correct and standard treatment for TB meningitis. The long duration of treatment is necessary to ensure that the bacteria are completely eradicated from your body and to prevent a relapse. The CT scan is a way for your doctor to monitor the healing process. While gliosis is not a cure in itself, it is a sign that your brain is attempting to repair itself. Your doctor will use your clinical symptoms, blood tests, and follow-up scans to determine if the infection is cured. The presence of gliosis is not a cause for alarm, but rather a testament to the battle your body has been fighting. It is a sign of an injury that is now healing.

question: What does the brain MRI report indicate?What does the following MRI of the brain report mean? There is a small chronic lacunar infarct versus a dilated perivascular space in the posterior left centrum semiolale. A small chronic lacunar infarct in the left thalamus is observed. There is no evidence of restricted diffusion to suggest acute infarction in the brain parenchyma. There is a mildly prominent CSF overlying the cerebral hemispheres secondary to moderate generalized cerebral and cerebellar volume loss rathat than subdural hygromas. The ventricles and basilar cisterns are normal in size.
human_answers: Lacunar infarctions are ischemic brain lesions less than 1cm in diameter. The first one described is not sure to be a infarction as it can also be a dilated perivascular space, witch can be be a variation of normal anatomy or changes through a persons life. I don't understand well the sentence before the last, but i suppose it's a brain atrophy caused by an old subdural hemorrhage. You should see a neurologist to value the risk factors for cerebral vascular disease and to treat the patient properly.
chatgpt_answers: The brain MRI report you have provided is describing several common findings that are not necessarily a cause for immediate alarm, especially in an older individual. The report points to changes in the brain that are often associated with the normal aging process and a history of chronic vascular issues. The key findings are: (1)Small chronic lacunar infarct versus a dilated perivascular space: This means the radiologist saw a small, fluid-filled space in your brain. A lacunar infarct is a small stroke that has healed, leaving behind a tiny cavity. A dilated perivascular space is a common, benign finding where the space around a blood vessel has simply become larger. The doctor is stating that the image could be either one, but both are considered chronic, meaning they are old and not a new or urgent problem. (2)A small chronic lacunar infarct in the left thalamus is observed: This is a more definitive finding of a small, old stroke in a part of the brain called the thalamus. Like the first finding, the word chronic is key, indicating that this is a past event and not something that is currently happening. (3) No evidence of restricted diffusion to suggest acute infarction: This is a very important and good piece of information. It means the MRI did not find any evidence of a new, or acute, stroke. (4) Mildly prominent CSF overlying the cerebral hemispheres secondary to moderate generalized cerebral and cerebellar volume loss: This is a description of brain atrophy, or shrinkage. As people age, it is normal for the brain to lose a small amount of volume. This shrinkage makes the fluid-filled spaces on the surface of the brain (the CSF spaces) look more prominent. The report is clarifying that this is a normal aging change and not a serious condition like a subdural hygroma. In summary, the report indicates that you have some normal, age-related changes in your brain, and it points to a history of what are likely a few very small, old strokes that you may not have even noticed. The most important thing the report says is that there is no evidence of a new stroke. This report is a snapshot of your brain's history, not a sign of a new or life-threatening condition.

The specific pain pattern—constant back pain that radiates to the breast—is a significant symptom that needs further investigation. In some cases, a doctor may prescribe stronger medication or recommend steroid injections. (2)Physical Therapy: A physical therapist can provide targeted exercises to strengthen core muscles, improve posture, and increase flexibility, which can help support the spine and reduce pain. (3)Heat and Cold Therapy: Applying a heating pad or a cold pack to the painful area can provide temporary relief. Heat can help relax tight muscles, while cold can help numb the area and reduce inflammation. (4)Lifestyle Adjustments: Maintaining a healthy weight, practicing good posture, and avoiding activities that worsen the pain are all important for managing symptoms. (5)Surgical Intervention: In severe cases where non-surgical treatments fail and there is significant nerve compression, surgery might be considered to decompress the nerves or stabilize the spine. Given the potential for more serious underlying conditions, it is imperative to seek a doctor's consultation immediately for a comprehensive evaluation and a proper treatment plan.

question: Q. How to get rid of the chickenpox scars?Hello doctor,I am suffering from chickenpox scars since childhood as it left so many marks and holes on my face. I need some suggestions to get rid of it. Please help.
human_answers: Hello. I understand that the chickenpox scars have been disconcerting to you. The treatment approach would depend on the depth of the wounds. Very deep scars would need a procedure like dermabrasion. For superficial scars, you can try Tretin 0.025 (Tretionin) cream daily night. Apply it in small amounts and very lightly over the scars, daily night for two months. It will not lead to a 100 % reduction in the scars, but it would gradually make the scars less visible by tightening the skin. If you are not satisfied with the results after two months, consult a local dermatologist for dermabrasion.
chatgpt_answers: Getting rid of chickenpox scars, especially those that have been on your face since childhood, can be a challenging process, but there are several effective medical and cosmetic treatments available. Scars from chickenpox are typically a type of atrophic or pockmark scar, which means they are indentations or depressions in the skin caused by the destruction of collagen during the healing process. While natural remedies like aloe vera or vitamin E can sometimes help with minor scarring, they are generally not effective for deep, long-standing scars. For a significant and noticeable improvement, professional treatments are usually required. The best course of action is to consult with a dermatologist who can assess the depth and type of your scars and recommend a personalized treatment plan. Common and effective options include: (1)Laser Resurfacing: This is one of the most popular and effective methods. Laser treatments, such as fractional laser or ablative laser, work by removing the outer layer of scarred skin and stimulating new collagen production, which helps to fill in the depressions and smooth out the skin's surface. (2)Microneedling: This procedure involves using a device with fine needles to create tiny punctures in the skin. This process triggers the body's natural healing response and encourages the production of new collagen and elastin, which can improve the texture and appearance of atrophic scars over time. (3)Chemical Peels: A dermatologist can apply a chemical solution to the skin to remove the damaged outer layers. Deeper peels can be very effective for atrophic scars, but they also require more recovery time. (4)Dermal Fillers: For a quick, though temporary, solution for a few deep scars, a dermatologist can inject a filler substance directly into the scar to raise the indentation and make it level with the surrounding skin. (5)Subcision: In this procedure, a needle is inserted under the skin to break up the fibrous tissue that pulls the scar down, allowing the skin to lift and the scar to become less noticeable. A dermatologist can help you decide which of these treatments, or a combination of them, is best suited for your specific skin type and the nature of your scars.

question: Q. Please go through my USG reports and suggest further course of action.Hello doctor,I am a 23 year old female. I am 19 weeks pregnant. The ultrasonography reports suggest the following:1. Bilateral 5 mm choroid plexus cyst.2. A small echogenic intracardiac focus in the left ventricle.

chatgpt_answers: For a 23-year-old female who is 19 weeks pregnant, the ultrasonography findings of a bilateral 5 mm choroid plexus cyst and a small echogenic intracardiac focus (EIF) in the left ventricle are relatively common findings that are often benign. The key point is that these are considered soft markers and not definitive diagnoses of a problem. (1)A choroid plexus cyst is a small, fluid-filled cyst in the brain's choroid plexus, the part of the brain that produces cerebrospinal fluid. These cysts are very common, and in the vast majority of cases, they resolve on their own by the third trimester. In isolation, a choroid plexus cyst is considered a normal variant and is not a cause for concern. (2)An echogenic intracardiac focus (EIF) is a bright spot on the ultrasound that is typically found in the heart's ventricles. It is thought to be a small calcium deposit on a papillary muscle. Like choroid plexus cysts, EIFs are quite common and are usually harmless. They do not affect heart function and often disappear on their own before birth. The reason these findings are mentioned is that, when seen in combination with other major abnormalities, or in a patient with other risk factors, they can be associated with a slightly increased risk of certain chromosomal abnormalities, such as Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome). However, based on your age (which places you in a low-risk category for chromosomal abnormalities) and the fact that these are the only findings in your report, your doctor will likely tell you that there is no need to be concerned. The standard course of action in your case would be to proceed with routine prenatal care. Your doctor may offer further genetic counseling or diagnostic testing, such as an amniocentesis, to provide complete peace of mind, but these are often not necessary unless other risk factors are present or other abnormalities are noted in a subsequent ultrasound.

question: Q. I have small cysts in my ovaries. Is this a serious problem?Hello doctor,I am a 19 year old female. I have small cysts in my ovaries. Is this a serious problem? Can you tell me in detail about it? I have attached my sonography report for your consideration.
human_answers: Hello. I read your query and went through your reports (attachment removed to protect patient identity). I hope this helps you. For more information consult a general practitioner online --> https://www.icliniq.com/ask-a-doctor-online/general-practitioner
chatgpt_answers: At 19 years old, the presence of small cysts in your ovaries is a very common finding and is almost always not a serious problem. The term you are likely hearing is Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) or a similar condition, but it's important to distinguish between having polycystic ovaries and having the full syndrome. Many women have small, fluid-filled sacs on their ovaries, which are essentially follicles that contain eggs and have not released them, giving the ovaries a polycystic appearance on an ultrasound. This is considered a normal variation and, on its own, does not cause any health problems. These types of cysts are not a sign of cancer and usually do not cause any pain or symptoms. They often come and go with your menstrual cycle. A serious problem arises when these cysts are accompanied by other symptoms that together form a syndrome, such as PCOS. The diagnosis of PCOS typically requires two out of three criteria: irregular or absent menstrual periods, signs of excess androgen (male hormones) such as acne or excessive hair growth, and the presence of polycystic ovaries on an ultrasound. If you only have the cysts without any other symptoms, your doctor's assessment will likely be that it is not a serious issue. However, if you are experiencing irregular periods, weight gain, or hormonal acne, then the presence of the cysts may point to PCOS, which can be managed with lifestyle changes and medication. Early diagnosis and management of PCOS can help prevent long-term complications, such as type 2 diabetes and heart disease. They can provide a definitive diagnosis and the appropriate guidance for your specific situation.

question: Suggest treatment for lump behind left earMy daughter is 4 years old and I noticed a lump behind her left ear. I also noticed small lumps in various spots on her scalp. In a four-year-old child, a lump behind the ear and on the scalp is most commonly an enlarged lymph node. Lymph nodes are a normal part of the immune system, and they often swell in response to a nearby infection, even one as common as a cold, a sore throat, or a minor ear infection. They act like filters, trapping germs, and can remain enlarged for some time after the infection has cleared. The fact that the doctor prescribed an antibiotic suggests they suspected a bacterial infection was the cause of the swelling. This is a standard and appropriate first step. The small lumps on her scalp are also likely swollen lymph nodes or, less commonly, a small benign cyst that is unrelated to the antibiotic treatment.The doctor's calm demeanor likely stems from the fact that this is a frequent finding in children and is usually not a sign of a serious condition. However, you should monitor the lumps closely. You should also watch for any other symptoms like a fever, a lack of energy, or if the lumps become red, warm, or very painful to the touch. If the lumps do not shrink or disappear after your daughter has completed the full course of antibiotics, or if they grow significantly, you should follow up with your doctor. In most cases, these lumps are harmless and will go away on their own, but a follow-up visit can provide you with peace of mind and ensure there are no other underlying issues.

question: Is it normal to have pain in chest after an year of bypass surgery?hi,this is a question about a 62 year old man (my father). he got his bypass surgery done a year ago and he has a pain in the center of his chest even after the surgery. do you suggest any test for the same or this is normal. his BP is also always high with 150-120 ratio.

Another possibility is that the pain is muscular or skeletal, perhaps related to the healing of the sternum or costochondritis (inflammation of the cartilage connecting the ribs to the breastbone). It is imperative that he see his cardiologist right away. The doctor will likely perform several tests to determine the cause of the pain, including an electrocardiogram (ECG), a stress test, and possibly a cardiac catheterization to visualize the grafts and arteries. His blood pressure should also be aggressively managed by a doctor, as bringing it under control is crucial for preventing future cardiac events and ensuring the long-term success of the bypass surgery.

A prescribed dose of 1.5 tablets per day is far from the six tablets you suspect she is taking. This is a very serious concern and could have dangerous consequences. Taking an excessive amount of Methylprednisolone can disrupt the body's natural hormone balance, particularly the adrenal glands, which are responsible for producing cortisol. Over time, the body's adrenal glands may stop producing their own cortisol, leading to a condition called adrenal insufficiency when the medication is stopped abruptly or the dosage is tapered too quickly. The symptoms you are describing—extreme fatigue, lethargy, and a feeling of being down—are hallmark signs of both high-dose corticosteroid use and, paradoxically, adrenal insufficiency. This is because high doses of the medication can suppress the body's natural energy systems and affect mood regulation. You should contact her doctor immediately to discuss your concerns about the dosage. Do not attempt to adjust her medication dose yourself. A doctor will need to perform a proper evaluation and create a safe plan to either correct the dosage or gradually taper her off the medication to prevent a medical crisis. A urologist, a doctor who specializes in the urinary tract and male reproductive system, will need to perform a procedure to reconstruct the urethra and close any secondary openings. chatgpt_answers: A loss of confidence, fear, and feeling of instability while walking, especially when accompanied by stage fear, suggests a psychological component rather than a physical one. Since this problem has been present for six months, it's possible that a traumatic event or a period of high anxiety has led to a condition known as psychogenic gait disorder. This is a functional neurological disorder where the brain's signals to the body are disrupted, resulting in walking difficulties, even though there is no underlying physical cause like nerve damage or a musculoskeletal issue. The stage fear you describe could be a manifestation of social anxiety, which is often tied to these types of physical symptoms. To rectify this, you must address both the physical and the psychological aspects of the problem. A good first step would be to consult with a neurologist to rule out any underlying neurological conditions. Once a physical cause is ruled out, the focus should shift to psychological and behavioral therapy. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is a highly effective treatment for this kind of anxiety-based condition. A therapist can help you identify the fears and anxieties that are causing your lack of confidence and work with you to re-train your thought patterns and behaviors. They will also provide you with exercises to help you feel more stable and confident on your feet. You can also benefit from physical therapy to improve your balance and gait, which will help to rebuild your physical confidence. By working with both a mental health professional and a physical therapist, you can address the root of the problem and regain your ability to walk boldly and without fear.

chatgpt_answers: The symptoms you are describing—a tender and bruised feeling in your stomach, along with slight nausea—in the period between ovulation and your expected period could be related to several factors, including early pregnancy symptoms or hormonal fluctuations of your menstrual cycle. While it is too early to know for sure if you are pregnant, some women report feeling a bruised or cramp-like sensation in their lower abdomen as a sign of implantation, which is when a fertilized egg attaches to the uterine wall. This is a common phenomenon and is often accompanied by a feeling of mild discomfort or twinges. However, this bruised feeling is also a symptom of premenstrual syndrome (PMS) that can be caused by the hormonal changes leading up to your period. These hormones, particularly prostaglandins, can cause muscle contractions in the uterus that may feel like a cramp or a sore, bruised sensation. To ease the discomfort, you can try some simple at-home remedies. Applying a warm compress or a heating pad to your lower abdomen can help relax the muscles and alleviate the cramp-like feeling. Over-the-counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen can also be effective, but you should avoid non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen if you think you might be pregnant. Light stretching and gentle exercise can also help to ease muscle tension. If the pain becomes severe or is accompanied by other concerning symptoms, such as sharp pain on one side of your abdomen or unusual bleeding, you should consult with a doctor to rule out other conditions.

question: What is the mediastynum cyst on the right side of my chest?Hi Doctor. I just got back from my CT scan. 3 months ago they located a 2 cm mediastynum cyst on the right side of my chest. My doctor sent me to get another CT 3 months later to see if it grew. Thy told me that it looks the same and that it is on the right side of my body near my heart. What should I do? And what is it?
human_answers: Respected user, hi I evaluated your query thoroughly .* Mediastinal cyst has vivid pathologies ranging from benign neuronal tumors   to malignant ones .* Mediastinal cyst evaluation needs correlation with detailed history of the    patient , clinical assessment , signs elicited by the consultant, exact location    in the mediastinum with in depth analysis of reports , Biopsy of the lesion   giving histopathological evidence of the disease.Hope this helps you.Welcome for any further queries.Thanks for using Healthcaremagic.com & giving me an opportunity to assist you.Wishing you healthy life ahead.Regards dear take care.
chatgpt_answers: A mediastinal cyst is a fluid-filled sac that is located in the mediastinum, the central compartment of the chest that separates the lungs. This area contains the heart, great vessels, trachea, and esophagus. The fact that the cyst is located on the right side and has remained stable in size over three months is reassuring and suggests that it is likely benign. The most common types of these cysts are bronchogenic cysts or pericardial cysts, both of which are usually harmless congenital abnormalities. Bronchogenic cysts are a result of abnormal budding of the developing airway, while pericardial cysts are congenital sacs of fluid near the heart. Neither of these is a form of cancer, and they are often discovered incidentally during imaging for other reasons. The standard course of action, which your doctor appears to be following, is watchful waiting with regular monitoring. Since the cyst has not grown, the current medical consensus is to leave it alone. The main risk is that the cyst could grow and press on a vital structure like your airway or a blood vessel, which could cause symptoms such as a cough, chest pain, or difficulty swallowing. However, since the cyst is small (2 cm) and stable, the risk of this happening is low. Surgery is generally only considered if the cyst grows, causes symptoms, or if there is any suspicion that it might be malignant, which is rare for this type of cyst. The recommended next step is to continue with the follow-up plan your doctor has laid out and to report any new symptoms you may experience.

question: What could cause skipping of heartbeat?hi just before i fall asleep or trying to falling asleep i feel like my heart is going to stop beating and i cant breath properly! Sometimes i actually fall asleep but wake up terrified cause i think my heart has stopped beating! Can this be anything serious??? Thank you in advance
human_answers: I read your question carefully and I understand your concern.Judging from that description I would say that a heart issue is very unlikely. One doesn't actually understand if heart has stopped beating, if it did there would be lack of blood flow to the brain which would cause lead to dizziness or fainting. I guess if one wanted to explore the issue to the end an EKG and perhaps a 24 hour Holter EKG (where you carry a device monitoring heart rhythm for 24 hours) may be done.However I believe the symptoms are most likely due to anxiety, which can often manifest this way, so nothing serious.I hope to have been of help.
chatgpt_answers: The sensation of your heart skipping a beat or feeling like it's going to stop, especially when you are falling asleep, is a very common and often frightening experience. This is known as a heart palpitation, and while it can feel terrifying, it is very rarely a sign of a serious, life-threatening condition. The feeling of being unable to breathe properly alongside the palpitations is also a common symptom. These sensations are often caused by premature heartbeats, which are extra, early heartbeats that disrupt the normal rhythm. Your body is highly attuned to these changes, especially when you are lying still and distractions are minimal, which is why you notice them more at night. The sudden, jolting feeling that your heart has stopped can also be related to hypnic jerks or sleep starts, which are involuntary muscle twitches that can occur as you drift off to sleep. They can be triggered by a sudden feeling of falling, and in turn, cause a rapid heartbeat and a feeling of panic. Other common causes of these symptoms are often not related to the heart itself and can include anxiety, stress, panic attacks, or certain lifestyle factors like high caffeine or alcohol consumption. However, because these symptoms are so distressing and can, in rare cases, be a sign of an underlying medical issue, it's crucial to consult a doctor. They will likely ask about your symptoms and medical history and may perform an electrocardiogram (ECG) to check your heart's electrical activity. In some cases, they may recommend a Holter monitor, a portable device that records your heart's rhythm over 24-48 hours, which can capture these events as they happen. While it is very likely that your symptoms are benign, seeking professional medical advice is the only way to get a proper diagnosis and the peace of mind you need.

The pain and numbness you are feeling are classic symptoms of nerve compression or nerve damage, likely originating from your spine. Since multiple conservative treatments have failed, it's crucial to seek further evaluation to get a definitive diagnosis. Conditions such as a herniated disc, spinal stenosis (a narrowing of the spinal canal), or sciatica (compression of the sciatic nerve) can all cause these debilitating symptoms. The weakness and numbness you describe indicate that the nerves controlling sensation and muscle movement in your legs are being affected. While the initial injections and other treatments may have been aimed at reducing inflammation, they may not be enough to relieve the pressure on the nerve. Your next steps should involve a more comprehensive approach. You should consult with a spine specialist, such as a neurologist or a neurosurgeon, who can perform advanced diagnostic tests. These tests may include an MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) to get a detailed view of your spine, discs, and nerves, and possibly an EMG (Electromyography) or nerve conduction studies to pinpoint exactly where the nerve damage or compression is occurring. Once the precise cause is identified, a new treatment plan can be developed. This might include different types of medication, or in some cases, surgery to decompress the nerve and alleviate the pressure. It is imperative that you get a clear diagnosis to move forward with a treatment that will actually work for your condition.

question: What causes meningitis in a baby?My brothers girlfriend uses meth-amphetamine.  Their baby was just admitted to the hospital for meningitis.  We dont know yet if viral or bacterial.   I know meningitis is associated with meth use. Could she or one of her "friends" have given the baby meningitis?
human_answers: meningitis is not related to Meth use. Meningitis in children offers due to infection most probably viral or bacterial. It is not related to drugs used by any close relative or friend. Take care.
chatgpt_answers: Yes, it's possible that the baby's meningitis could be related to the mother's or her friends' methamphetamine use, though it is not a direct cause. Methamphetamine abuse does not directly cause meningitis. Instead, it suppresses the immune system and can compromise the integrity of the blood-brain barrier , making the body more susceptible to infections. This increased vulnerability means that a person using meth is at a higher risk of contracting a bacterial or viral infection that could then lead to meningitis. The most common causes of meningitis in a baby are bacterial or viral infections. In newborns, bacteria like Group B Streptococcus (GBS), Escherichia coli (E. coli), and Listeria are the most common culprits, often transmitted from the mother during or shortly after birth. In older infants, the infection can be spread through respiratory droplets from coughing, sneezing, or close contact with someone who is a carrier, even if the person doesn't show symptoms. Therefore, if the mother or her friends were carrying a contagious germ that causes meningitis, they could have transmitted it to the baby, whose immature immune system would be less equipped to fight it off. The baby's hospitalization for meningitis is a very serious medical event, and the hospital staff will conduct tests to identify the specific pathogen, which is crucial for determining the correct treatment and prognosis.

question: Q. Will I be made comfortable during getting anesthesia for wisdom tooth removal?Hello doctor,Today I got my wisdom teeth pulled and they said they were gonna give me a shot in my mouth. There is no way I will be relaxed. Is there any option they would do for me to be more comfortable?
human_answers: Hi. Yes, this is the only way to get local anesthesia. You can also go for general anesthesia but it will be too costly and needs hospitalization. It is a simple procedure, and you will only feel a prick like an insect bite. Do not worry, it is simple and there will be no pain during the procedure. If you are too apprehensive tell your doctor that apply some local anesthesia at the site of the prick, you will then even not feel the prick too.
chatgpt_answers: For most wisdom tooth extractions, local anesthesia is the standard procedure, and it is administered via an injection into the gums to numb the area. It is completely normal and understandable to feel anxious about this, and you should know that there are several options available to help you feel more comfortable and relaxed during the process. The most common option to alleviate anxiety is sedation dentistry. This is an excellent alternative that allows you to be fully relaxed without being completely unconscious. The most common types of sedation include: Nitrous Oxide (Laughing Gas): This is a very common option. You simply inhale the gas through a small mask placed over your nose. It helps you relax and reduces pain perception. The effects wear off very quickly once the mask is removed, and you can usually drive yourself home. Oral Sedation: Your dentist can prescribe an oral medication, such as an anti-anxiety pill, for you to take about an hour before your procedure. This will make you drowsy and very relaxed, though you will remain awake and able to respond to commands. You will need someone to drive you home afterward. Intravenous (IV) Sedation: This is a stronger option that is administered through a vein in your arm. It provides a deeper level of relaxation, making you feel like you are in a twilight state. You will likely have little to no memory of the procedure. A trained professional must administer this type of sedation, and you will definitely need a ride home. Before your appointment, you should express your concerns to your dentist and ask about these options. They will be able to discuss your medical history and help you choose the best and safest method to ensure you are comfortable and relaxed throughout the procedure.

Clomid works by stimulating ovulation, which you've already confirmed occurred on day 13. Duphaston, a progestogen, is then used to support the uterine lining and prepare it for a potential pregnancy, and its effectiveness is generally not compromised by a viral infection like a cold. question: Which medicine among hydracortesones, thyroxine and sinemet can drop blood pressure?When I get up in morning by blood pressure is fairly normal then I take two hydracortesones 10mg and a thyroxine 125 mcg and sinemet 25/100 and my pressure drops dramatically to like 90 over 55. question: Are Carob products safe to eat after gall bladder removal?Hello,      I'm curious to know if carob products are safe to eat after gallbladder removal since that I'm aware that chocolate is to be avoided after gall bladder surgery even though that a person might eat it sparingly ? chatgpt_answers: After gallbladder removal (cholecystectomy), the body's ability to digest fats is altered because bile, which helps break down fats, is no longer stored and concentrated in the gallbladder. Instead, it flows directly from the liver into the small intestine in a continuous, less concentrated stream. This is why many people are advised to avoid high-fat and greasy foods, like certain types of chocolate, which can cause digestive issues such as bloating, gas, and diarrhea. Regarding carob, it is generally considered a safe alternative to chocolate after gallbladder removal because it is naturally low in fat. The concerns with chocolate are primarily due to its high fat content from cocoa butter. Since carob powder is derived from a bean and is typically fat-free, it does not pose the same risk of digestive discomfort. Many recipes using carob are also low in fat, which aligns well with post-cholecystectomy dietary recommendations. However, it is important to be mindful of any other ingredients in a carob product. For instance, a carob bar might contain added fats or oils to achieve a creamy texture, which could potentially cause a reaction. Therefore, the safety of any carob product depends on its overall fat content. The best approach is to start with a small amount and monitor how your body responds. As a general rule, focusing on a low-fat, high-fiber diet with smaller, more frequent meals can help your body adjust and minimize any digestive issues.

question: Suggest treatment for MVP and increased heart beat during pregnancyHello. I'm a 38-year-old female. I'm 5 months pregnant. I have MVP. However, the increased frequency is likely due to the significant physiological changes your body is undergoing during pregnancy. Your blood volume increases by 30-50%, forcing your heart to work harder and pump more blood. This can put extra stress on the heart and often causes an increase in the frequency of palpitations. Given your history and the new symptoms, you should be concerned enough to inform your doctor, but not so concerned that you panic. The best course of action is to schedule a visit with your doctor or cardiologist. They will need to perform an evaluation to ensure that your heart is handling the increased workload of pregnancy appropriately. The good news is that for most women with MVP, pregnancy is uneventful. If the extra beats are found to be benign, your doctor may recommend lifestyle modifications to help manage them, such as staying well-hydrated, avoiding caffeine and other stimulants, and getting adequate rest. They can also provide reassurance to help ease your anxiety, which itself can be a major trigger for palpitations.

question: What causes swelling in gums after tooth extraction?i had a molar pulled out last thursday and since then ive notice that my back molar has my gums all swollen around it.. it dont really hurt its more like its uncomfortable.. why is this happening?? human_answers: HiIt could be due to traumatic extraction or there might be some remaining root.If it doesn't resolve with in 5 days after taking medicines then go x-ray to rule out if there is some remaining root stump.Continue with your medicines for 5 days.Also do warm saline rinses 3-4 times a day.Visit your dentist for further consent.RegardsDr. Neha Sumra
chatgpt_answers: It is very common and normal to experience some swelling in the gums around the site of a tooth extraction, especially around the adjacent teeth. The swelling you are noticing on your back molar is likely a natural part of the healing process. When a tooth is pulled, the surrounding tissues, including the gums, bone, and ligaments, are subjected to a significant amount of trauma. This triggers a localized inflammatory response, which is the body's way of sending blood and immune cells to the area to begin the repair process. This inflammation typically manifests as swelling, redness, and a feeling of discomfort or tenderness. The discomfort you're feeling is likely due to the pressure from this swelling on the surrounding tissues. Additionally, if the extraction was a lower molar, the swelling can sometimes affect the surrounding muscles, causing some stiffness in the jaw and a feeling of discomfort. The sutures, or stitches, that your dentist placed are designed to hold the gum tissue in place, protect the surgical site, and aid in the healing process. They can also contribute to the feeling of tightness and discomfort in the area. Given that your pain is minimal and the feeling is one of discomfort rather than severe pain, it is not a sign of a major complication. The swelling should start to subside over the next few days, and your dentist will be able to assess the healing process when you go in to have your stitches removed. However, if the swelling worsens, if you develop a fever, or if the pain becomes severe and throbbing, you should contact your dentist immediately, as these could be signs of a dry socket or an infection.

question: Does eczema cause greenish stool in kids?Hello,I have a seven week old baby, for the last couple of days she has been having yellowish/greenish stool with white little stringy things in her stool. I am not quite sure if this is normal. She has gotten eczema recently, so I'm not sure if that has something to do with it.
human_answers: Eczema does not cause greenish stools in kids and I do not find any association. Greenish stools occur due to rapid transit of faecal matter through the large intestine and is normal in babies of such an age. Probably you are giving formula feeds, at least partly, and since they are hard to digest, often white portions are present in the stool. It is normal too. No need to worry.
chatgpt_answers: There is no direct causal link between eczema and a child having greenish stool. Eczema is a skin condition caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors that lead to skin barrier dysfunction and inflammation, and it does not directly affect the digestive system or the color of a baby's stool. The greenish color and the presence of white, stringy things in your seven-week-old's stool are most likely normal occurrences for an infant of that age. In babies, stool color can change frequently depending on what they are consuming and how fast the milk moves through their digestive system. A greenish or mustard-yellow color is very common in breastfed infants, and it can also appear if a baby is getting more of the watery foremilk than the fattier hindmilk. The small white, stringy things you've noticed are likely undigested milk protein or fat from the formula or breast milk. This is a normal finding and is not a cause for concern. While eczema does not cause changes in stool color, it is worth noting that in some cases, a baby's eczema may be an external symptom of a food allergy or sensitivity, such as to a protein in cow's milk. If this were the case, the allergy could also cause digestive issues that might manifest as changes in the stool, but the eczema itself is not the direct cause. If your baby seems to be in good health otherwise, with no fever, signs of dehydration, or excessive fussiness, the stool changes are likely part of normal infant development. However, if the stool becomes consistently watery or watery with blood, or if your baby seems to be in discomfort, you should consult with a pediatrician to get a proper evaluation.

question: Which beta blocker is safe in asthma and with least side effects?I have Asthma and am looking for the beta blocker that has the least side effects and I need to print this information to make a comparison, but it s not printing the information, mostly blank pages. If there is a charge for your reply, please do not reply.
human_answers: Hello and Welcome to ‘Ask A Doctor’ service.I have reviewed your query and here is my advice. We recommend  selective beta blockers  such as Nebivolol.However you should discuss this with your doctor. RegardsDr.Jolanda
chatgpt_answers: As a person with asthma, selecting a beta-blocker requires careful consideration because these medications can cause the airways to narrow, potentially triggering an asthma attack. The safest beta-blockers for patients with asthma are typically cardioselective beta-blockers, which primarily target the beta-1 receptors in the heart and have less of an effect on the beta-2 receptors in the lungs. Among the cardioselective beta-blockers, bisoprolol (Zebeta) and metoprolol (Lopressor, Toprol XL) are generally considered to be the safest and are most often prescribed to asthma patients. Studies have shown that these medications cause significantly less bronchoconstriction and have minimal effects on lung function at low doses compared to non-selective beta-blockers. Other cardioselective options include atenolol and nebivolol. Non-selective beta-blockers like propranolol and carvedilol should be avoided, as they block both beta-1 and beta-2 receptors and pose a much higher risk of causing a severe asthma exacerbation. It is crucial to note that while cardioselective beta-blockers are a safer option, they are not entirely without risk. The selectivity is dose-dependent, and at higher doses, they can lose their selectivity and affect the lungs. Therefore, if you are prescribed a beta-blocker, your doctor will start you on the lowest possible dose and monitor your respiratory symptoms closely. It is essential to discuss this with your doctor, as they are the only person who can properly assess the risks and benefits for your specific condition and decide on the best and safest treatment for you. To print this information, you can use your browser's print function. On most computers, you can press Ctrl + P (for Windows) or Cmd + P (for Mac) to open the print dialog box. From there, you can select your printer and adjust settings before printing the page.

question: Could scoliosis with a growth spurt cause a chest lump?My 9 year old son woke up 2 days ago with a painful lump on his chest. I took him to our family doctor and she took xrays and the xrays showed a curve in his spine. She is sending us to a specialist because she thinks he might have Scoliosis. Could a growth spurt and having Scoliosis caused this lump?
human_answers: Hello, There is no association between a growth spurt & scoliosis and the painful chest lump that your son has. Could the lump have been the result of an injury? Hope I have answered your query. Let me know if I can assist you further. Take care Regards,Dr Arnold Zedd, Pediatrician
chatgpt_answers: It is highly unlikely that a growth spurt or the onset of scoliosis would directly cause a painful, palpable lump on your son's chest. Scoliosis is a condition characterized by an abnormal curvature of the spine, and a growth spurt is the most common time for it to appear or worsen. While a severe spinal curvature can sometimes cause the ribs to become uneven or protrude, this is typically a gradual process that doesn't manifest as a sudden, painful lump. The pain and the distinct lump are more indicative of a localized issue. The most probable cause of a sudden, painful lump on the chest is either a costochondritis, an inflammation of the cartilage connecting the ribs to the breastbone, or a minor muscle injury. Another possibility could be an abscess or cyst, though those are less common. The doctor's focus on scoliosis from the X-rays is a separate but important finding that needs to be evaluated by a specialist. However, this spinal curve is not likely the cause of the sudden lump you observed. The doctor's next step in sending you to a specialist is correct, as scoliosis requires careful management to prevent progression. While the scoliosis and the lump are two different issues, it is good that the lump prompted a visit that led to the discovery of the scoliosis. You should ask the specialist for an opinion on the lump as well, as they will have more experience with the musculoskeletal system.

question: What causes fluctuations in the BP level in a lung and liver cancer patient?Someone I know has been on this for awhile and has been getting great results I have noticed her belly is getting big and her blood pressure is going up and down. She has been diagnosed with stag 4 cancer liver lung pelvis cancer do you know if this mean it is getting close to dieing I am close to the family I just want to be prepared for them or is it hard to say thanks
human_answers: if patient's tummy is getting distended that signifies that she might be developing ascites (accumulation of fluid in the tummy )or disease is spreading.so it's a poor prognosis and survival is maximum upto 6 months in these cases
chatgpt_answers: I'm very sorry to hear about your friend's situation. It's an incredibly difficult time, and it's thoughtful of you to want to be prepared to support their family. In a patient with advanced-stage cancer of the liver and lungs, blood pressure fluctuations are a common and serious symptom, and they can be caused by a variety of factors related to the progression of the disease and its treatments. The liver is a critical organ for regulating blood pressure, metabolism, and fluid balance, so as cancer progresses in the liver, its ability to perform these functions is compromised. The swelling of the abdomen, known as ascites, is a common sign of advanced liver cancer, which is caused by a buildup of fluid and often goes hand-in-hand with blood pressure irregularities. The cancer's effect on the lungs can also compromise the body's oxygenation, which in turn affects blood pressure. While fluctuations in blood pressure and swelling can be a sign of a decline in a patient with advanced-stage cancer, it is impossible to say with certainty whether it indicates that the end is near. A patient’s body can go through periods of rapid decline and then stabilize for a time. These symptoms may also be managed with medication to control blood pressure and diuretics to reduce fluid buildup. The best way to understand the patient’s prognosis is for a close family member to have an open and honest conversation with their hospice or palliative care team. They can provide the most accurate assessment of the patient's condition and help the family prepare for what's to come, both physically and emotionally.

question: Why has doctor told me to do barium CT scan?I have been told that from an ultrasound I had looking at my gallbladder that the gallbladder checked out fine but that there is a shadow at the tip of my pancreas. I have been told that I need a berium CT scan follow up. Is this something that is serious. I am a 30 year old male with no other medical conditions.
human_answers: Hi, dearI have gone through your question. I can understand your concern.You have gone through ultrasound for gall bladder. Your gall bladder is normal but there is shadow at tip of pancreas. It can be pancreatic cyst or some mass in pancreas. So to diagnose the cause CT scan is required. So go for it. It can be benign lesion or can be malignant. But investigations are required. So consult your doctor and plan accordingly.Hope I have answered your question.
