chatgpt_answers: Your doctor has ordered a barium CT scan because the initial ultrasound, while confirming your gallbladder is fine, detected an abnormality—a shadow—on your pancreas. An ultrasound can sometimes show a mass or a shadow that is not clearly defined, and a CT scan with a contrast agent like barium is the next logical step. The barium you will drink helps to coat the lining of your esophagus, stomach, and intestines, making them more visible on the CT scan. This improved clarity will allow the doctors to get a much more detailed image of your pancreas and the surrounding area. While the term shadow can sound alarming, it simply means that something was seen that requires a closer look. It could be a benign pseudocyst, a fluid-filled sac that is often a result of pancreatitis, which is inflammation of the pancreas. It could also be an entirely harmless anatomical variation. However, since the pancreas is a critical organ, and the symptoms of pancreatic cancer are often subtle and can go undetected for a long time, doctors are vigilant about investigating any abnormality. Therefore, the doctor is being cautious and thorough by ordering this follow-up scan. While it is understandable to be concerned, the fact that you are a 30-year-old male with no other medical conditions makes it statistically less likely that this is a serious issue. The best approach is to follow through with the barium CT scan as your doctor has instructed. The results of this scan will provide the information needed to get a definitive diagnosis and determine the next steps, if any.

question: Is lump after banged to the coffee table something wrong?Hi, I have just banged my leg on the corner of my coffee table. Below the right knee to the right hand side, It actually brought tears to my eyes. It came up in a bruise straight away an now there is a hard round lump underneath the bruise. is the lump anything bad do you think?
human_answers: Hi,The lump is a normal occurrence after this type of injury. There will be swelling and bruising which will have caused blood to collect in the area causing the lump to appear. It may last a few days before receding. In the meantime, take paracetamol and ibuprofen for the pain. Keep your knee moving with your normal daily activities otherwise it may become stiff. A compression knee support may help. Also try a cool compress to the area. Hope this helps you. Regards,Dr K A Pottinger
chatgpt_answers: No, a hard, round lump that appears immediately after you bang your leg on a coffee table is a very common and normal physiological response to an injury. The lump is not inherently bad, but is actually a sign of the body's natural healing process. The sharp impact of hitting your leg caused immediate tissue damage to the small blood vessels beneath your skin, which is why you saw a bruise appear so quickly. This bruise is a collection of blood that has leaked out of those damaged capillaries. The hard, round lump underneath it is likely a combination of two things: first, the hematoma, which is a more localized collection of blood that has clotted and solidified, creating the hard feeling. Second, the lump is also caused by inflammation and swelling as your body rushes fluids and immune cells to the site of the injury to begin repairing the damaged tissue. While the pain and the sight of the lump and bruise can be alarming, they are typically signs of a minor injury. You can help reduce the swelling and discomfort by applying a cold compress or ice pack to the area for 15-20 minutes at a time, several times a day. You can also elevate your leg to help reduce blood flow to the area. The lump and bruise should gradually go down over the next few days to weeks. However, if the lump becomes extremely painful, grows significantly larger, or you experience numbness, tingling, or difficulty moving your leg, you should consult with a doctor to rule out a more serious injury, such as a fracture.

chatgpt_answers: The symptoms your son experienced—throat pain, difficulty swallowing, and continuous coughing—are classic signs of an allergic reaction. The best course of action is to continue to work closely with her medical team. chatgpt_answers: Thank you for your question, Sarah. This is a very important concern for a patient with dermatomyositis, as it is an autoimmune disease and can often involve medications that suppress the immune system. The oral polio vaccine (OPV), which is a live, weakened virus vaccine, can indeed pose a risk to people who are immunocompromised. The live virus in the vaccine can replicate in the child’s intestines and be shed in their stool for several weeks after vaccination. For most healthy people, this poses no risk, and it can even provide a form of passive immunization to those in close contact. To protect yourself, the most critical precaution is to avoid contact with your granddaughter's stool and to practice meticulous hygiene for at least six weeks after she receives the oral polio vaccine. This means avoiding diaper changes and ensuring that you and everyone else in the household wash their hands thoroughly and frequently, especially after using the bathroom or handling your granddaughter. While the risk is considered low, especially for those not on high-dose immunosuppressive therapies, taking these precautions is a simple and effective way to ensure your safety. It is also a good idea to discuss this with your own rheumatologist and your granddaughter's pediatrician to get specific guidance tailored to your health status and any medications you may be taking.

question: Why would a patient with esophageal cancer have a feeding tube inserted surgically into the duodenum ?Why would a patient with esophageal cancer have a feeding tube inserted surgically into the duodenum and not into the stomach? chatgpt_answers: A patient with esophageal cancer would have a feeding tube, known as a jejunostomy tube (J-tube), surgically placed into the duodenum (the first part of the small intestine) instead of the stomach for several critical reasons. The most common reason is that the cancer itself is located in the esophagus, which often makes it difficult or impossible for the patient to swallow food or liquids. In many cases, the tumor may extend into or affect the stomach's ability to function properly, or the stomach may be used in the surgical reconstruction of the esophagus. Furthermore, placing the feeding tube in the stomach (a gastrostomy tube or G-tube) is often a poor choice because of the high risk of aspiration. When a feeding tube is in the stomach, there is a risk that the contents can be regurgitated back up the esophagus and inhaled into the lungs, leading to a serious lung infection like aspiration pneumonia. By placing the tube directly into the small intestine, doctors can bypass the stomach entirely and deliver nutrients directly to where they are absorbed. The duodenum is a safer and more effective location because it has a lower risk of reflux and aspiration, ensuring that the patient receives the necessary nutrition to maintain their strength and health during cancer treatment.

The safest course of action is to discuss your specific situation with both your oncologist and your cardiologist. They can provide personalized advice based on your current health status and the results of your most recent medical tests. You should not rely on general information or take the risk without first consulting with your medical team.

In your case, with your job requiring you to stand for over nine hours a day, the continuous pressure on your feet has likely caused your body to form these bony growths as a protective measure. While they are a sign of the body trying to repair itself, these spurs can press on surrounding nerves, ligaments, and soft tissues, causing significant pain and limiting your mobility, which explains why you are experiencing so much pain and have difficulty walking. Regarding surgery, whether it is worth it is a decision that must be made in consultation with your orthopedic surgeon, as it depends on the severity of your condition and the extent to which the pain is affecting your life. While it is an emotionally devastating time, knowing that you can still provide comfort and support is important. I strongly advise you to have an open and honest conversation with the medical team about the current prognosis and available palliative care options to help you and your family prepare for what lies ahead.

question: Q. What are the chances of HIV transmission through mosquitoes?Hello doctor,Regarding the transmission of HIV by mosquitoes, I have following query. I know the virus does not survive in insects, but what if some mosquito bites a very high viral load HIV-infected person and then bites an uninfected person on his wound, who crushes it on his wound. If the above situation happens at three or four places on his body simultaneously by an HIV-infected mosquito, what is the possibility of HIV transmission by this method?
human_answers: Hi. It is good that you have an interest in HIV transmission. Hope your query is answered, but if you have any other question, please do not hesitate to ask or call anytime. For more information consult an HIV AIDS specialist online --> https://icliniq.com./ask-a-doctor-online/HIV-AIDS-specialist
chatgpt_answers: Your query touches on a very common and understandable fear, but the medical community has extensively studied this possibility and concluded that HIV transmission through mosquito bites is not possible. The scenario you've described, where a mosquito bites a person with a high viral load and is then crushed on an open wound, would still not lead to HIV transmission. There are a few key biological reasons for this. First, the HIV virus cannot survive or replicate inside a mosquito's body. Unlike viruses that mosquitoes do transmit (like the malaria parasite or dengue fever), HIV is treated as a food source by the mosquito's digestive system and is quickly broken down and destroyed. Second, a mosquito's feeding mechanism is not a simple transfer of blood. A mosquito has two tubes in its mouthparts: one to inject saliva to prevent clotting and another to draw blood. A mosquito does not inject the blood from a previous meal into the next person it bites, so there is no transfer of infected blood. Finally, the amount of virus that would be present on a mosquito's mouthparts, even in the scenario you described, is far too small to cause an infection in a new person. For these reasons, public health organizations like the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) have stated unequivocally that there is no risk of HIV transmission from mosquitoes or other insects.

Since the stone is in the kidney itself and not yet in the ureter, it may not be causing any pain or symptoms. The most important step for you to take is to schedule an appointment with a urologist who can review the scan, discuss her symptoms, and recommend the best course of action.

However, if your symptoms are not improving after two days on amoxicillin, it could be a sign that the infection is resistant to this antibiotic, or that the infection is more severe than anticipated. This makes it even more crucial that you see a dentist as soon as possible. They can properly diagnose the problem, prescribe the most effective antibiotic, and perform the necessary dental procedure to resolve the infection permanently. Continuing to self-medicate with different antibiotics without a professional diagnosis is a risk to your health and will only delay the definitive treatment you need.

question: Suggest remedy for slow blood flow to heart and walls of heart not thickeningHi, may I answer your health queries right now ? Went through all of the tests and my cardiologist said looks like possible blockage, says heart wall not thickening. Went for Angiogram Dr says arteries perfect. Any suggestions? What would cause a slow flow to the heart and the walls not thickening?
human_answers: Helloit's a very good news that your coronaries are absolutely fine.Now what causes the slow flowy is the fat deposits inside the lumen of the arteries which starts at an age of 3 years. omega 3 fatty acids do help so u can start taking them in a dosage of one capsule a day. Hope that your concern has been taken care of.
chatgpt_answers: Based on the information you have provided, your situation is complex and requires careful consideration, especially since your symptoms of chest pain and shortness of breath are persistent, despite a clear angiogram. While an angiogram is excellent at identifying blockages in the major coronary arteries, it does not always capture the full picture of cardiovascular health. A clear angiogram combined with symptoms and a non-thickening heart wall suggests that the problem may not be in the large arteries but rather in the microvasculature, or small blood vessels, of the heart. This condition is often referred to as coronary microvascular dysfunction (CMD) or small vessel disease. In CMD, the tiny blood vessels in the heart don't function properly, leading to a slow flow to the heart muscle even though the main arteries are clear. The heart wall not thickening is another important clue. A healthy heart muscle thickens and contracts with each heartbeat to pump blood effectively. When the walls do not thicken, it can indicate a problem with the muscle itself, possibly due to a lack of adequate blood supply, or another underlying issue. This could be related to conditions like cardiomyopathy, where the heart muscle itself is abnormal, or it could be a consequence of the slow blood flow due to the microvascular dysfunction. Since your cardiologist has ruled out a major blockage, the next logical step is to explore other possibilities. It is highly recommended that you seek a second opinion from a cardiologist who specializes in coronary microvascular disease or heart failure. They can suggest further testing, such as a Cardiac PET scan, a stress echocardiogram, or a cardiovascular MRI, to get a more detailed look at the heart muscle and blood flow. These tests can often reveal issues that an angiogram might miss. They may also consider a different class of medication to help manage your symptoms and improve blood flow. It's crucial not to dismiss your symptoms just because the angiogram was clear. The remedy in this case is not a quick fix but a dedicated effort to find the right diagnosis and work with a specialist to develop a targeted treatment plan.

question: Suggest treatment for azoospremiaHi,I m 37 yrs old (183cms/75kgs), got married 9 yrs ago, no kids, tested and found azoospermia(less semen counts), underwent varicocele surgey 18 months back, no improvement, wife(31 yrs old/58 kgs) is alright. What is the alternate solution to give birth to a child?
human_answers: you should go for a testicular biopsy.. maybe the biopsy will reveal sperms in the testicular tissue that could be used for an IVF cycle.. IVF might be the only possible way for you to have children..goodluck
chatgpt_answers: Azoospermia is a condition where there is a complete absence of sperm in the ejaculate, and it can be a complex challenge for couples trying to conceive. Given that you have already undergone varicocele surgery with no improvement, it is important to understand that varicocelectomy is not always successful in restoring sperm production, especially in cases of non-obstructive azoospermia where the issue is with sperm production itself, rather than a blockage. The fact that your wife's health is alright is a good sign, as this allows you to focus on male-factor infertility treatments. The most promising alternative solution for you and your wife would be assisted reproductive technologies (ART), which directly address the problem of no sperm in the ejaculate. The primary method for a couple in your situation is to explore sperm retrieval techniques in combination with in vitro fertilization (IVF) and intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI). Even with non-obstructive azoospermia (a likely diagnosis given the lack of success with your varicocelectomy), many men have small, localized areas within their testes that still produce sperm. Procedures such as microscopic testicular sperm extraction (micro-TESE) can be performed to surgically retrieve these sperm directly from the testicles. The retrieved sperm, even if found in very small numbers, can then be used in an IVF cycle. During the IVF process, a single sperm is injected directly into an egg, a technique known as ICSI. This bypasses the need for large numbers of motile sperm and has allowed many men with azoospermia to become biological fathers. Before moving forward, you should consult with a reproductive urologist or a male fertility specialist who can conduct a thorough evaluation, which may include hormone tests and genetic screening, to determine the exact cause of your azoospermia and to identify the best approach for sperm retrieval. If surgical sperm retrieval is not successful, a final option would be to use donor sperm for an intrauterine insemination (IUI) or IVF cycle.

You can improve your weight by making strategic changes to your diet and exercise routine. The first step is to focus on a diet rich in nutrient-dense, calorie-dense foods. Instead of just eating more of the same foods, incorporate healthy fats, proteins, and complex carbohydrates. For example, add avocados, nuts, nut butters, and olive oil to your meals. To track your intake and ensure a calorie surplus, consider using a food journal or a calorie-tracking app. While exercise may seem counterproductive if you're losing weight, the right type of exercise is crucial for building muscle, which is a key part of healthy weight gain. Instead of focusing on cardio, which can burn a lot of calories, switch to resistance training or weightlifting. This type of exercise builds muscle mass and can also increase your appetite. question: Taking Zithromax and Ventolin for chest infection and cold. Can smoke marijuana or cigarette without effecting antibiotics?I ve had a chest infection and a cold for about four days now. Zithromax (azithromycin) is an antibiotic designed to kill the bacteria causing your chest infection, and Ventolin (albuterol) is a bronchodilator that helps open your airways to make breathing easier. The smoke can also introduce new irritants and increase mucus production, which can create a more favorable environment for bacteria to thrive. Even if you are feeling better, your lungs are still in a sensitive state of recovery. To ensure the antibiotics work as effectively as possible and to prevent a relapse of your infection, it is best to avoid all forms of smoking until you have fully recovered and have completed your full course of antibiotics as prescribed by your doctor. question: Is  2-3/hpf pus cells count normal in toddlers?For my 1.6 year son today urine test is done since it was yellow in color & the result is: the Pus cells count is 2-3/hpf & Epithelial cells is 2-3/hpf & RBC is 0-1/hpf. chatgpt_answers: A finding of 2-3/hpf (high power field) pus cells in a toddler's urine sample is generally considered a low number and may not be a cause for significant alarm on its own. It is a common finding, and a small number of these cells can be present in a urine sample without indicating a serious problem. Similarly, a count of 2-3/hpf for epithelial cells and 0-1/hpf for red blood cells (RBCs) are also within or very close to the normal range for many laboratories. Epithelial cells are shed from the urinary tract and their presence is normal, while a single red blood cell can be a result of contamination or other minor factors. However, the reason for the urine test—the urine being yellow in color—is also a factor. While concentrated urine that is very yellow can simply be due to mild dehydration, it can also be a sign of a urinary tract infection (UTI), especially if it's accompanied by other symptoms like fever, fussiness, or changes in urination patterns. In a toddler, a UTI can present with very subtle signs, and a low pus cell count might be the only indicator. Given the presence of even a small number of pus cells, it is prudent to follow up with a doctor. The results, while not immediately alarming, suggest that a deeper look may be needed. When you are able to get to a doctor, they may want to re-test the urine, perhaps with a more sterile sample collection method, to confirm the results. They will also be able to correlate the lab findings with your son's overall health and any other symptoms he may have. In the meantime, ensure he is well-hydrated to help flush his system.

Some migraines, known as vestibular migraines, can cause dizziness and nausea even without a headache. Less common but serious causes could include a neurological issue or even a sudden drop in blood pressure when changing positions. question: What is meant by focal wall calcification?Ultrasounds shows a 11 mm left renal cyst.  A bright echo with equivocal shadowing is seen along posterior margin and could represent a calcification.  No evidence of hydronephrosis. chatgpt_answers: Focal wall calcification, in the context of your ultrasound report, refers to a specific area of calcium deposits that have formed on the wall of the kidney cyst. To break it down, focal means it's localized to one spot, wall refers to the boundary of the cyst, and calcification means it's a hardened area of calcium. When an ultrasound describes a bright echo with equivocal shadowing, it's the radiologist's way of saying they see a very dense, bright spot that is casting a shadow, which is characteristic of a hard material like calcium. In most cases, a small, simple kidney cyst with a focal wall calcification is a benign finding and is often the result of an old, resolved issue or the natural aging process. They are generally not a cause for major concern. However, in some instances, a complex cyst, particularly one with calcifications, can have a very small association with more serious conditions like malignancy, though this is rare. The term equivocal in the report means the finding is ambiguous, and the radiologist is suggesting it could be a calcification but is not 100% certain. Your report also notes no evidence of hydronephrosis, which is a good sign as it means there is no blockage or swelling of the kidney. While the report's impression suggests that the cyst is likely harmless, the best course of action is to follow up with your doctor. They will be able to interpret the results in the context of your overall health history, and may recommend a follow-up ultrasound in 6 to 12 months to ensure that the cyst and the calcification have not changed in size or appearance. This is a standard and cautious approach to monitor such findings and is not a reason to be overly worried.

chatgpt_answers: SGPT (serum glutamic pyruvic transaminase), now more commonly known as ALT, and SGOT (serum glutamic-oxaloacetic transaminase), or AST, are enzymes that act as indicators of liver health. Normal ranges for these enzymes can vary slightly between labs, but generally, SGPT is considered normal between 7-56 U/L and SGOT is normal between 5-40 U/L. With your SGPT at 57 and SGOT at 52, both of your readings are slightly elevated. This may not be a major cause for alarm on its own, as a single, slightly high reading can be influenced by factors such as recent strenuous exercise, certain medications, or minor infections. However, persistently high levels can suggest an underlying issue with the liver. While a high SGPT/SGOT level is a sign of potential liver stress or damage, it is not a direct cause of giddiness. Your frequent giddiness is more likely a symptom of an underlying condition that is also causing the liver enzyme elevation. For example, conditions such as viral hepatitis, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, or even certain medications can lead to both liver enzyme elevation and symptoms like nausea, weakness, or fatigue, which can contribute to giddiness. Your overall health status, including your weight and blood pressure, also plays a role. Given that your other medical check-up results were normal, it's important to discuss the elevated liver enzymes with your doctor. They may recommend further investigations to determine the root cause, such as a follow-up blood test to see if the levels are trending down or remaining elevated. Your doctor can provide a definitive diagnosis and an appropriate course of action, which may include lifestyle changes, such as maintaining a healthy weight and diet, to help improve your liver health.

A positive TMT, also known as a cardiac stress test, is a significant finding because it indicates that there is a problem with the heart's blood supply. Even though she has no history of high blood pressure or diabetes, and her blood sugar is normal, a positive TMT strongly suggests that there may be a blockage in her coronary arteries, a condition known as coronary artery disease (CAD). A positive TMT in the absence of other risk factors and symptoms like chest pain can be a tricky case. The shortness of breath, anxiety, and headaches, however, can all be related to this underlying heart issue. Shortness of breath is a classic symptom of reduced blood flow to the heart muscle, especially during exercise. The anxiety and headaches can also be secondary symptoms of a stressful cardiac event or a physical response to reduced oxygenation. Her slightly elevated cholesterol level of 204 mg% is another piece of the puzzle, as high cholesterol is a primary risk factor for CAD. Given these findings, the most important step for treatment is to confirm the diagnosis of CAD. The gold standard for this would be a coronary angiogram, which provides a detailed look at the coronary arteries to pinpoint any blockages. Based on the results of the angiogram, the treatment could range from lifestyle modifications and medication to more invasive procedures. Lifestyle changes would include a heart-healthy diet low in saturated fats and sodium, a regular exercise program (supervised by a doctor), and managing stress. Medications could include beta-blockers, statins to lower cholesterol, and antiplatelet drugs like aspirin. If the blockage is severe, procedures like angioplasty with stenting or bypass surgery might be necessary. The key is to address the underlying cardiac issue to alleviate the symptoms of shortness of breath, anxiety, and headaches.

question: Is oral vaccination for Hep A and Typhoid B available?I am planning to travel to India from Canada for 3 weeks and want to know if A) I should take vaccination for Hep A and Typhoid B) If yes, is it possible to take oral medication when I arrive in India for the above 2. I was told that I can take Immunogolublin and Vivotif when I arrive in India.
human_answers: Hello, Oral vaccine for typhoid is available. However, it is not available for HAV. Hope I have answered your query. Let me know if I can assist you further. Regards,Dr. Loveleen Sharma, General & Family Physician
chatgpt_answers: For your trip to India, it is highly recommended that you get vaccinated against both Hepatitis A and Typhoid fever as both diseases are common in many parts of the country and are transmitted through contaminated food and water. While there are oral vaccinations available for some of these diseases, it's not the case for all of them, and the timing of your travel makes a key difference. There is no oral vaccine for Hepatitis A. The vaccine is given as an injection into a muscle. Typically, the Hepatitis A vaccine is a two-dose series for long-term protection, with the second shot given at least six months after the first. However, a single dose is highly effective and can provide protection for at least one year, making it a viable option for your three-week trip. The vaccine should ideally be administered at least a couple of weeks before travel for the best effect. The option you were told about, Immunoglobulin, is not a vaccine. It's a type of treatment made from human blood plasma that provides immediate, short-term protection by giving your body pre-made antibodies. It is typically used for people who need immediate protection or who are at a higher risk of serious illness from Hepatitis A. It only provides protection for up to two months and is not a substitute for a long-term vaccine. Yes, an oral vaccine for Typhoid fever is available. The oral vaccine, often known by the brand name Vivotif, is a series of capsules that must be taken every other day for a total of four doses. The full series must be completed at least one week before you travel to be effective.  Since your trip is for three weeks, and a full course takes over a week, you would need to start taking it before you leave Canada. It is not advisable to wait until you arrive in India to get either of these vaccinations. Vaccines need time to stimulate your immune system and build up antibodies for protection. For both vaccines, it is best to get them well in advance of your trip. Therefore, you should consult a travel clinic or your doctor in Canada to discuss the best vaccination schedule for your trip. They can provide you with the necessary vaccinations and ensure you are protected before you leave.

question: Suggest treatment for swelling in the entire scrotal sacI had hydrocele surgery 10 days ago. Now I have severe swelling in the entire scrotal sac which is the size of a softball. human_answers: Hi,A hydrocele is an accumulation of peritoneal fluid in the scrotum and surgical drainage of the fluid is done to treat the condition. If the hydrocele is uncomplicated, the doctor makes an incision directly into the scrotum. After the canal between the abdominal cavity and the scrotum is repaired, the hydrocele sac is removed, fluid is removed from the scrotum, and the incision is closed with sutures.10 days is a very short time for the surgical wound to heal completely. The hydrocele sac has been removed surgically and now the fluid is accumulating in the scrotum. This will be present for some time until it gets absorbed in to the body. There can be some swelling for the first 2 - 3 weeks after surgery and few people also experience bruising of scrotal skin. Please wear loose clothes and have a scrotal support as suggested by your surgeon.

While some swelling is expected after any surgery, the extent you describe—the size of a softball—and its persistence despite a course of ibuprofen and cephalexin is not a normal post-operative course. The fact that you have pre-existing lymphedema is a crucial piece of information that likely complicates your recovery. Lymphedema is a condition of chronic swelling caused by a compromised lymphatic system, and a surgery in a nearby area can easily disrupt the already fragile lymphatics, leading to an exacerbation of fluid buildup. The lack of improvement after several days on antibiotics suggests that the swelling may not be primarily due to an infection that cephalexin would address. Instead, it is likely that the swelling is a severe form of post-operative edema, possibly a lymphocele (a collection of lymphatic fluid), or a hematoma (a collection of blood), which would explain why the antibiotics are not working. In such cases, the treatment is not just medication. You must contact your urologist again immediately and inform them that the swelling has not improved with the prescribed medication. They may need to perform a new examination and an ultrasound to determine the exact cause of the swelling. Depending on the findings, the treatment could include a new course of action, such as draining the fluid with a needle, or more aggressive measures to manage the lymphatic fluid buildup. Given your pre-existing lymphedema, it is vital to have a specialist who is knowledgeable about managing both conditions. You should not wait for the swelling to subside on its own, as it could lead to complications and a delayed recovery.

question: What causes low blood pressure in young adult?My daughter fainted at work tonight. We have been taking her blood pressure and it is running 100/60 to 80/40 when lying down. In a young, healthy individual like your daughter, who is an ex-athlete and does not smoke or drink, the most common causes of low blood pressure are often temporary and related to lifestyle. Dehydration is a primary culprit, as it reduces the body's blood volume. This can be exacerbated by hot environments or strenuous physical activity. Another common cause is orthostatic hypotension, which is a sudden drop in blood pressure when moving from a lying or sitting position to standing, and is caused by the body's inability to adjust blood flow quickly enough. It is also possible that a more serious underlying issue is at play, such as a heart condition, an endocrine problem, or even a nutritional deficiency. Given that your daughter has already fainted and her blood pressure has dipped to 80/40, it's wise to be cautious. While her feeling a bit off now is a good sign, a reading that low can lead to organ damage if not corrected. The plan to have her seen by a doctor tomorrow is a good one, but if her blood pressure drops further or she begins to feel dizzy, disoriented, or nauseous, it is crucial that you take her to an emergency room immediately. chatgpt_answers: The symptoms you've described for your grandmother, including the sensation of her head or the environment spinning around and a feeling of pressure on her head, are a classic presentation of vertigo. The inability to use a phone receiver is likely a direct result of the vertigo, as it makes it difficult to hold her head in a steady position without triggering the spinning sensation. The feeling of pressure on the head can be a secondary symptom. One of the most common causes of vertigo in older adults is Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV). This condition is caused by dislodged calcium crystals in the inner ear that move into a part of the ear where they don't belong, sending incorrect signals to the brain about the body's position and movement. A change in head position, such as lying down, getting out of bed, or looking up, often triggers a spinning sensation that can be quite intense but is usually short-lived. While BPPV is a frequent cause, other potential issues could be at play, and some are more serious. A different inner ear disorder, such as Meniere's disease, could also cause these symptoms, sometimes accompanied by a ringing in the ears or hearing loss. In some cases, the symptoms can also be a sign of a cardiovascular issue, such as a drop in blood pressure, or even a neurological problem. Given your grandmother's age and the severity of her symptoms, you should not wait to see if it improves on its own. The most important step is to take her to a doctor or an emergency room immediately. A doctor will need to perform a physical examination, potentially including specific head movements to diagnose BPPV. Once a diagnosis is made, the treatment can be simple and highly effective. For BPPV, a series of head movements called the Epley maneuver can be performed by a medical professional to reposition the crystals in the inner ear. For other causes, such as cardiovascular or neurological issues, further testing and a different treatment plan would be necessary. In the meantime, ensure she moves slowly and carefully to avoid a fall, and that she has someone to assist her.

question: What does elevated ESR and CRP indicate?My daughter has had a low grade fever for approximately two weeks.  She had a similar fever one month ago. chatgpt_answers: Elevated Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR) and C-Reactive Protein (CRP) are both non-specific markers of inflammation in the body. When a child has a persistent low-grade fever, as your daughter has had for two weeks, and these markers are elevated, it strongly suggests that her immune system is actively responding to an underlying issue. The combination of a fever, a mild cough, and nasal congestion, even in a child with seasonal allergies, points towards a respiratory infection. For example, it could indicate a bacterial infection, which would not resolve on its own. It could also suggest a chronic inflammatory condition, such as juvenile idiopathic arthritis or inflammatory bowel disease, which can present with systemic inflammation and fever. The fact that she suffers from seasonal allergies is an important part of the picture, as allergies themselves are a form of inflammation. While allergies can cause nasal congestion and a cough, they typically do not cause a fever or a significantly elevated ESR/CRP. Therefore, the elevated markers are more likely related to an infection or another inflammatory process that is occurring alongside her allergies. Given these findings, your pediatrician is likely to recommend further investigation, which may include a more specific blood test, a chest X-ray, or even a referral to a specialist to get to the root of the problem. BPPV is the most frequent cause of vertigo and is characterized by a spinning sensation that occurs with specific changes in head position, such as lying down, rolling over in bed, or looking up. This happens when tiny calcium crystals in your inner ear, which are crucial for balance, become dislodged and move into the wrong place. While the meclizine you were prescribed can help manage the immediate feelings of dizziness and nausea, it is not a long-term solution. The most effective treatment for BPPV is a series of specific head and body movements known as canalith repositioning procedures, with the Epley maneuver being the most common. These maneuvers are designed to physically move the dislodged crystals back to their correct location in the inner ear. You mentioned that physical therapy helped before, and it is likely that a physical therapist or a doctor trained in these maneuvers can help you again. For a reoccurring episode, it's advisable to revisit your doctor or physical therapist. They can confirm the diagnosis and perform the Epley maneuver in the office, which often provides immediate relief. They can also teach you how to perform a modified version of the maneuver at home, so you are prepared to manage future episodes on your own. question: Could pain in lower back and abdomen after unprotected sex mean pregnancy?I have been trying to get pregnant but we only just started trying about 2 weeks ago.  We had sex 3 times without a condom.  Now for the past 4 days ive been experiencing lower back pain and abdominal pain. It feels like my period will be here tomorrow but it just never comes. But i also feel its way too soon to have any pregnancy symptoms.
human_answers: Hallow Dear,The cardinal and first symptom of pregnancy is missed period. Though it is not absolutely clear from your history whether you have missed your period or not, the impression I got is you have not missed period. Even if you have missed period, the other following symptoms start appearing after about 10 days or so after missed period. These symptoms are:1. Nausea & Vomiting and Pica2. Frequent urination3. Breast symptoms: Engorgement with tenderness, dark discolouration of nipples and areola with increase in areolar size, Montgomery's tubercles under areola and secretions from the nipples. Pain is not a feature of normal uneventful pregnancy without any risk. Appearance of pain anytime during pregnancy is indicative of some risk to the pregnancy. If you have missed your period, you can confirm the diagnosis of pregnancy by performing pregnancy test on overnight first early morning urine sample 8-10 days after missed period. Earlier these tests may give false negative results. Alternatively, you may opt for Beta hCG test which gives reliable results even few days before missing period. Abdominal pain with low back ache is a classic feature of amoebic colitis which can be treated with Metronidazole. In this condition, the stools are stained with blood and/or mucous. I hope this helps you. Dr. Nishikant Shrotri

The timing of your symptoms, feeling like your period is about to start but it never comes, is a very common experience for many women in the days leading up to their period. Both premenstrual syndrome (PMS) and early pregnancy can cause very similar symptoms, including bloating, cramping, and backaches. The reason for this overlap is that both are heavily influenced by the same hormones, especially progesterone. However, the fact that you feel these symptoms a bit earlier than usual could be a hint. Some women report experiencing very mild cramping and backaches about a week or two after conception, which is often referred to as implantation cramping. This happens as the fertilized egg burrows into the uterine lining. The pain is usually much less intense than typical period cramps and may feel more like a pulling or tingling sensation. Since it has only been about two weeks since you started trying, it is indeed very early to have definitive pregnancy symptoms. The most reliable way to know for sure is to wait until your period is actually late and then take a home pregnancy test. In the meantime, the back and abdominal pain could also be related to the sex itself. Rough or prolonged intercourse can sometimes cause temporary muscle strain or irritation, leading to discomfort. The best approach is to wait a few more days to see if your period begins, and if it doesn't, a pregnancy test will give you the most accurate answer.

This is a testament to the quality of the initial procedure and your excellent oral hygiene. The life expectancy of a root canal-treated tooth, especially a front tooth like an incisor, can be very long. While an average is often cited as 10 to 15 years, it's not uncommon for these teeth to last a lifetime with proper care. The fact that your front teeth are incisors is a major advantage, as they are not subjected to the heavy chewing forces that molars are, which makes them less prone to fracturing. The dental crown you have on them also plays a crucial role, as it acts as a protective shield, strengthening the tooth and preventing it from becoming brittle or cracking over time. However, no dental procedure can be guaranteed for a lifetime, and it's good to be prepared for what might happen if one of your teeth were to fail. A root canal can fail for a variety of reasons, such as a new infection, a crack in the tooth, or a breakdown of the filling material. When this happens, there are a few options. The first and most common option is to have a root canal retreatment. In this procedure, the dentist reopens the tooth, removes the old filling material, cleans the canals again to eliminate the new infection, and then refills and reseals the tooth. This is often successful and can give the tooth many more years of life. If retreatment is not an option, or if it is unsuccessful, the next steps are more invasive. One alternative is an apicoectomy, a minor surgical procedure where a surgeon removes the tip of the tooth's root and seals it to prevent further infection. This is often considered when the infection is localized at the very end of the root. The last resort is to have the tooth extracted. While this is often the final option, it opens the door to new replacement solutions, such as a dental implant or a dental bridge. A dental implant is often considered the gold standard for replacing a missing tooth, as it looks and feels like a natural tooth and can last a lifetime.

question: Cellular and deep penetrating fibrous histiocytoma, CD43 positive in blood vessels. Cancer?I have recently been told that a lesion removed from my leg is cellular and deep penetrating fibrous histiocytoma.My doctor wants to do a wider excision of the area again. He said he is confident about the outcome but local recurrence can happen. Is this cancer?  It said in the report it was CD43 positive in blood vessels.
human_answers: Fibrous histiocytoma is a type of tumor that does not spread to other parts of the body. However it is a locally aggressive tumor and recurs locally even after adequate surgery. So, recurrence at the same site after inadequate surgery is almost sure shot. Thus, a wide excision of the area is mandatory. As, i said, local recurrence can still happen, but the chances are much less. CD 43 positivity in this setting means nothing and doesnt change either the outcome or the treatment plan.
chatgpt_answers: This is a complex diagnosis, and it's understandable that you're concerned and looking for clarity, especially when the word histiocytoma is used. A cellular and deep penetrating fibrous histiocytoma is generally considered a benign or low-grade malignant tumor. While it is not a classic, aggressive cancer, its classification is more nuanced. The term cellular and deep penetrating are key. Cellular indicates that it is composed of a dense collection of cells, which can sometimes be a characteristic of more aggressive tumors. Deep penetrating means it extends into the deeper layers of the skin, such as the fat and muscle, making it more difficult to completely remove in a single procedure. Because of this, it has a high rate of local recurrence, which is why your doctor is recommending a wider excision. He is likely very confident because this is the standard treatment to ensure all tumor cells are removed, which drastically lowers the chance of it returning. Regarding the CD43 positive in blood vessels finding, this is a detail from a special type of diagnostic test called immunohistochemistry. It means that the cells within the tumor expressed a protein called CD43. While CD43 is a marker often found on white blood cells, its presence in this context is often used to help pathologists confirm the diagnosis of a histiocytoma and rule out other, more aggressive types of tumors like a sarcoma. In the context of a fibrous histiocytoma, the CD43 positivity helps to confirm the specific cell type of the tumor and is not a direct indicator that it is a widespread or life-threatening cancer. In summary, a cellular and deep penetrating fibrous histiocytoma is a tumor that can behave aggressively by growing and recurring locally, but it rarely spreads to other parts of the body (metastasizes). Your doctor is taking the right and most common course of action by performing a wider excision to remove the lesion entirely and minimize the chances of a recurrence. His confidence in the outcome is likely based on the fact that this is a very treatable condition with the proper surgical intervention.

This process can remove the corn entirely, including its core, which is often the source of the pain. Without these preventative measures, the corn is likely to recur over time. Given the longevity and severity of his condition, it would be wise for your husband to consult with a podiatrist who specializes in laser treatments. They can properly assess his foot, determine if he is a good candidate for the procedure, and create a comprehensive long-term plan to keep his feet pain-free.

Endometriosis occurs when tissue similar to the lining of the uterus grows outside of the uterus. This tissue can attach to organs in the pelvic region, such as the ovaries, fallopian tubes, and the outer surface of the uterus. During the menstrual cycle, this misplaced tissue also responds to hormonal changes, leading to bleeding, inflammation, and the formation of scar tissue, which can cause the severe pain you're experiencing. While the pain of endometriosis often gets worse during menstruation, it is not uncommon for it to be present at other times as well, which could explain why your symptoms have no link to when you're on your period. The severity of the pain does not always correspond to the extent of the disease. Furthermore, endometriosis is a leading cause of infertility. The inflammation and scar tissue it creates can obstruct the fallopian tubes or cause other issues that make it difficult for a woman to conceive. The reason your previous scans may have come back inconclusive is that endometriosis is notoriously difficult to diagnose with standard imaging tests like ultrasounds or CT scans, as the lesions are often too small to be seen. The gold standard for a definitive diagnosis is a laparoscopy, which is a minimally invasive surgical procedure where a surgeon inserts a small camera through a tiny incision to look for and, in some cases, remove the endometrial tissue. You should seek a second opinion from a gynecologist who specializes in treating endometriosis. They can discuss your symptoms, review your medical history, and recommend a diagnostic laparoscopy to get a definitive answer and, if the condition is found, start a treatment plan that can help manage your pain and improve your chances of conceiving.

In this case, the location is in the upper part of your left lung. The use of questionable indicates that the finding is not clear enough to be definitive, which is why your doctor ordered a follow-up test. The second result, APICOLORDOTIC VIEW SUGGESTED FOR FURTHER EVALUATION, is the radiologist's recommendation for the next step. An apicolordotic view is a specialized x-ray that is taken with the patient leaning back to get a clearer picture of the upper lungs, specifically the apices, which are the very top parts of the lungs. This area can be difficult to see on a standard chest x-ray because of the clavicle (collarbone) and other surrounding bones. The radiologist is suggesting this view to get a better look at the area where the questionable infiltrates were seen. The most important suggestion for you is to follow up with your doctor and get the recommended apicolordotic view done as soon as possible. This is not a diagnosis of a serious disease, but a recommendation to investigate further. The infiltrates could be a sign of a number of things, ranging from a minor and resolved infection, like a mild case of pneumonia, to something that needs more attention, like tuberculosis, a fungal infection, or a non-cancerous lesion. In some cases, a small infiltrate can even be a remnant of a previous lung infection. The next x-ray will provide a clearer picture and help your doctor determine if any further testing or treatment is needed.

question: Q. I have severe hair loss after hair straightening. What should I do?Hello doctor,I had got my hair straightened twice this year. Now, I face severe hair loss. Even my scalp is visible on one side. What should I do now?
human_answers: Hello. Continue these for a month and then you can consult me again. Good luck. For more information consult a dermatologist online --> https://icliniq.com./ask-a-doctor-online/dermatologist
chatgpt_answers: When hair straightening, especially multiple times in a short period, results in severe hair loss and a visible scalp, it's a clear sign of a significant underlying issue. The chemical processes and high heat used in hair straightening can cause damage in two primary ways. First, they can weaken the hair shaft itself, leading to breakage. This type of damage can make your hair look thinner and cause it to snap off easily. Second, and more seriously, the chemicals and heat can damage the hair follicles on your scalp, which can lead to a type of hair loss known as chemical-induced alopecia. The fact that your scalp is visible on one side suggests that the damage is severe and possibly localized. The first and most important step you need to take is to immediately stop all chemical and heat treatments on your hair. Any further stress on your scalp could worsen the damage and make it more difficult for your hair to recover. You should also be very gentle when you wash, comb, or style your hair. Use a wide-tooth comb and avoid pulling or tugging. You should consult a dermatologist or a trichologist, a specialist in hair and scalp health. They can perform a thorough examination to determine the exact cause and extent of the hair loss. A dermatologist can help determine if the hair follicles have been permanently damaged or if they are just in a temporary state of shock. Depending on their findings, they may recommend a variety of treatments. These could include a topical treatment to stimulate hair growth, a change in your hair care routine to use gentler products, or in some cases, a more advanced treatment to help restore your scalp health. It's crucial to seek professional help as soon as possible, as early intervention can sometimes prevent permanent damage.

This type of reaction can occur within a few minutes to a few hours after eating the offending food. The hives or rash can appear as red, raised, and itchy bumps that can be localized to one area, like your arms, and then spread to other parts of your body, like your chest. It's also common for the itching to come and go. It's important to try and identify what food might have caused this reaction. Since you are experiencing a rash and itching, taking an over-the-counter antihistamine can often help to alleviate the symptoms. However, if you experience more severe symptoms like difficulty breathing, swelling of the face, lips, or throat, or a sudden drop in blood pressure, you should seek immediate medical attention, as this could be a sign of a life-threatening allergic reaction called anaphylaxis. In the meantime, you should try to pinpoint what you ate today that might be new or different and avoid it to prevent a future reaction.

While cleaning the tongue is a good practice, it may not be addressing the root cause of your halitosis. Small pockets in the tonsils, known as tonsil crypts, can trap food particles, bacteria, and mucus. You may not be able to see them in a mirror, and they can be difficult to dislodge. Other potential causes include gum disease (gingivitis or periodontitis), where bacteria accumulate around the gumline and cause inflammation and odor, or even sinus issues like chronic post-nasal drip. When mucus from your sinuses drains down the back of your throat, it can become a breeding ground for odor-causing bacteria. Systemic issues like acid reflux or gastrointestinal problems can also contribute to bad breath. To get to the bottom of this, you should first consult a dentist. They can perform a thorough examination of your teeth, gums, and tongue to rule out any dental issues. If your dentist finds nothing wrong, they may recommend you see an ear, nose, and throat (ENT) specialist. An ENT can examine your tonsils and sinuses to see if either of those are the source of the problem. They may be able to provide a solution such as professional cleaning of your tonsil crypts or, in some cases, a surgical procedure to address the root cause of your bad breath.

chatgpt_answers: A diagnosis of AFB negative but PCR for M. tuberculosis positive can be confusing, but it's a significant finding that requires immediate attention and treatment. Here's a breakdown of what the results mean. An AFB (Acid-Fast Bacilli) smear is a rapid but less sensitive test that looks for tuberculosis bacteria under a microscope. A negative result means there were not enough bacteria in your sample to be seen, which is common in cases where the disease is less active or located in a part of the body other than the lungs. The PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) test, on the other hand, is a highly sensitive molecular test that looks for the DNA of M. tuberculosis in your sample. A positive PCR result means that the DNA of the bacteria was detected, confirming that you have a tuberculosis infection. This result is more reliable for a definitive diagnosis than a negative AFB smear alone. You should not seek a second opinion but should instead follow your doctor's recommendation and start treatment immediately. Tuberculosis is a serious infectious disease that requires a multi-drug treatment regimen, and delaying treatment can lead to the disease becoming more severe and difficult to treat. Your doctor will likely prescribe a combination of antibiotics to be taken for several months. Regarding your ability to conceive, having a tuberculosis infection, especially if it is in an extrapulmonary location (outside the lungs), can potentially affect your fertility. Tuberculosis can spread from the lungs to other parts of the body, including the reproductive organs, where it can cause scarring and damage. However, with proper treatment, the infection can be cured, and the chances of a successful pregnancy can be greatly improved. It is crucial to have a detailed discussion with your doctor about your desire to conceive. They can work with you to ensure that the medication is safe for you, and that you get the right advice on how the treatment may impact your ability to get pregnant in the future.

chatgpt_answers: Your diagnosis of thrombocytopenia, a condition characterized by a low platelet count, is a serious medical issue that needs to be addressed with your healthcare team. The fact that your platelet count has been fluctuating significantly—from 50, to 40, to 30, and then up to 75—shows that your body's ability to produce or maintain platelets is being compromised. Platelets are crucial for blood clotting, and a low count puts you at an increased risk of bleeding and bruising. While it's understandable that you are curious about the cause and want to find a quick fix, it's very important to let your doctors continue their investigation. There are many potential causes of thrombocytopenia, and they range from a minor issue to a very serious one. The most common cause is Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP), which is an autoimmune disorder where your immune system mistakenly attacks and destroys your own platelets. Other causes can include a viral infection (like mononucleosis or HIV), certain medications, an underlying bone marrow disease, or an enlarged spleen. Your mild depression is also an important factor, as there is some research suggesting a link between stress and low platelet counts, but it is unlikely to be the sole cause of such a significant drop. Regarding vitamins and supplements, you should not take any without consulting your doctor first. While some supplements like folic acid, vitamin B-12, and vitamin C can be helpful if the thrombocytopenia is caused by a nutritional deficiency, taking them without a proper diagnosis could be ineffective or even harmful. For example, some herbs and supplements can interfere with platelet function and make the condition worse. The only safe and effective way to manage your condition is to work with your doctors to determine the root cause. A definitive diagnosis is the key to a successful treatment plan, which may include medication to suppress the immune system, or in some cases, a change in diet or other lifestyle factors.

When you fell, the force of your body was transferred to your arms and wrists, which can easily overstretch or tear the ligaments and muscles in those areas. The fact that you don't think anything is broken is a good sign, as a fracture would likely cause more severe pain, swelling, and an inability to move the limb. The best and most common first aid for this type of injury is to follow the R.I.C.E. protocol. Rest the injured arm and wrist. Avoid using them as much as possible to prevent further injury and allow the tissues to heal. Ice the area for 15-20 minutes at a time, several times a day. This will help to reduce the swelling and pain. Compression is also helpful; you can use a bandage to gently wrap the area, which will help to reduce swelling, but make sure it is not too tight. Finally, Elevate your arm on pillows whenever you are sitting or lying down to help the fluid drain away from the injury. You can also take over-the-counter anti-inflammatory pain relievers like ibuprofen or naproxen to help with the pain and swelling. However, if the pain gets worse, if you notice significant swelling or bruising, or if you are unable to move your fingers or wrist, you should see a doctor immediately. A doctor can perform a physical examination and may order an X-ray to confirm that there is no fracture.

question: I am having obsessive compulsive disorderi am having obsessive compulsive disorder from 2 years..my problem is neatness..i will clean my house 100 times...even it is neat i am unable to stop this..i am on tab..fluoxatine..should i have to be on life long therapy??any permanent cure??

chatgpt_answers: Dealing with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), especially when it has such a significant impact on your daily life, is a very challenging and distressing experience. It is not something you should be ashamed of, and it is a very real medical condition. The fact that you are aware of your behavior—cleaning your house 100 times even when it is already neat—is a sign that your mind is in a constant state of anxiety, and the compulsive behavior is a way for you to temporarily relieve that anxiety. The use of a medication like Fluoxetine (Prozac) is a very common and effective first-line treatment for OCD, as it helps to regulate the levels of serotonin in your brain, which plays a key role in mood and anxiety. However, medication alone is often not a permanent cure for OCD. The most effective long-term solution is a combination of medication and psychotherapy, specifically a type of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) called Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP). ERP is considered the gold standard of treatment for OCD. In this therapy, a trained therapist will help you gradually and safely expose yourself to the situations that trigger your obsessions and then teach you to resist the urge to perform the compulsive behaviors. For example, you might be asked to deliberately make a small mess and then resist the urge to clean it. Over time, this helps to break the link between the obsession and the compulsion and can significantly reduce the anxiety. Regarding the question of lifelong therapy, the goal of treatment is not to be in therapy forever, but to gain the skills and tools to manage your OCD on your own. Many people with OCD find that a combination of medication and therapy can lead to a significant and lasting reduction in their symptoms. The need for medication can vary from person to person. Some people may be able to wean off their medication after a long period of successful therapy, while others may need to stay on it for a long time to keep their symptoms at bay. The key to a permanent cure is to get a proper diagnosis and work with a therapist and a doctor who can help you with a comprehensive treatment plan.

Taking it every other night is unlikely to be as effective as taking it every day and could lead to a return of your hay fever and asthma symptoms. The fact that a full tablet or even a half tablet every night causes depression in you is a serious side effect that needs to be addressed with a medical professional. You should contact your doctor or a pharmacist immediately and inform them of the side effects you are experiencing. chatgpt_answers: When liver function tests show elevated levels of AST (aspartate aminotransferase) and ALT (alanine aminotransferase), it is a clear sign of liver cell damage or inflammation. These enzymes are primarily found in the liver, and when liver cells are injured, they release these enzymes into the bloodstream, which is what your blood test has detected. While a single elevated reading can sometimes be a temporary fluctuation, your numbers—AST 121 and ALT 92—are significantly above the normal range and warrant a closer look, especially given your medical history. Your doctors are likely considering several factors that could be contributing to these elevated levels. One of the most common causes of liver enzyme elevation is your hemochromatosis. This is a genetic disorder that causes your body to absorb too much iron, and the excess iron can accumulate in organs like the liver, leading to damage. The fact that you are being treated with phlebotomies (blood removal) is a good step, but it is possible that the hemochromatosis is still causing some liver inflammation, especially if the iron levels are not yet fully controlled. Another very possible cause is the medication you have been on for 10 years, sertraline. While it is a safe and commonly used antidepressant, it is well-known to cause an increase in liver enzymes in some people, particularly with long-term use. This can be a sign of drug-induced liver injury. The effects can be mild, but in some cases, a change in medication is necessary. Other potential causes that your doctors will want to rule out include viral hepatitis (A, B, or C), a fatty liver (often associated with metabolic syndrome), or other conditions that can affect the liver. Given your medical history, it is crucial that you continue to work with your doctor. They may want to do a more thorough investigation, which could include a viral hepatitis panel, a re-evaluation of your sertraline dosage, or a closer look at your hemochromatosis management to pinpoint the exact cause of your elevated liver enzymes.

Sperm need to have good motility to be able to travel from the vagina, through the cervix and uterus, and into the fallopian tubes to fertilize an egg. The World Health Organization (WHO) has set a standard for this, and a rapid linear progression of 2% is a very low number that would certainly make natural conception difficult. A low rapid linear progression does not mean that your husband is completely infertile, but it does mean that the chances of conceiving without medical intervention are low. The urologist can perform a thorough examination and may recommend further tests to determine the underlying cause of the low motility. This could be due to a number of factors, including a varicocele (swollen veins in the scrotum), hormonal imbalances, a nutritional deficiency, or a lifestyle factor. Once the cause is identified, a treatment plan can be created. This could include a combination of things. For example, if a varicocele is the cause, a surgical procedure to repair it can sometimes significantly improve sperm motility. The urologist may also recommend lifestyle changes, such as a healthier diet, regular exercise, and avoiding certain habits, as well as a regimen of vitamins and supplements, such as Coenzyme Q10 and L-Carnitine, which have been shown to improve sperm quality and motility. In many cases, these treatments can improve the chances of a natural conception. If they are not successful, there are still other options, such as Intrauterine Insemination (IUI) or In Vitro Fertilization (IVF), which have a very high success rate in these situations. The most important thing is to seek professional help and not give up hope.

A rectocele, also known as a posterior vaginal prolapse, occurs when the rectum bulges forward into the back wall of the vagina. This bulging is caused by a weakening of the rectovaginal septum, the thin wall of tissue separating the rectum from the vagina. When you are constipated and straining to have a bowel movement, the pressure in your rectum increases, which can push the weakened rectal wall into the vagina, causing the lump you're feeling. This bulge can also make it difficult to have a complete bowel movement, creating a vicious cycle of straining and constipation. The thick, white, stringy mucus discharge is also likely related, as your rectum is trying to pass stool and is producing mucus in response to the irritation and constipation. While a rectocele is not a life-threatening condition, it can be very uncomfortable and can worsen over time. The best course of action is to make an appointment with a gynecologist or a colorectal specialist. They can perform a physical examination to confirm the diagnosis and can also rule out other possibilities, such as a cyst or a hemorrhoid. They can also provide a treatment plan. In many cases, a rectocele can be managed with conservative treatments, such as a high-fiber diet to prevent constipation, drinking plenty of water, and avoiding straining during bowel movements. In more severe cases, a surgical procedure may be recommended to repair the weakened tissue and prevent the bulge from recurring.

In the meantime, you can try wearing a wrist splint at night to keep your wrist in a neutral position, which can help to relieve the pressure on the nerve. question: Can an acid reflux event cause a rapid heart rate?Can an acid reflux event cause a rapid heart rate? My resting rate is in the high 50's. Rabies is almost always fatal once symptoms develop. The fact that the doctor advised passive immunization is based on established medical guidelines for post-exposure prophylaxis. Here is the breakdown of why the doctor's advice is the correct course of action. Rabies post-exposure prophylaxis has two components: active immunization and passive immunization. (1)Active immunization is what your neighbor is receiving with the Rabipur vaccine. This vaccine stimulates her body to produce its own antibodies against the rabies virus. This process takes time—about 7 to 10 days—to become effective. (2)Passive immunization involves giving the patient rabies immune globulin (RIG). This is a fast-acting shot that provides immediate antibodies to the patient, offering a crucial layer of protection in the period before the vaccine can take full effect. This is especially important for deep or severe bites. The veterinarian's advice, while well-intentioned, is based on a different set of protocols. While a dog that remains healthy for 10 days after a bite is unlikely to have been shedding the rabies virus at the time of the bite, it is a risk that human medicine does not take. The doctor's advice is in line with the World Health Organization (WHO) and other global health organizations' guidelines, which strongly recommend a combination of a vaccine and immune globulin for high-risk exposures.

question: Q. Food gets stuck while entering my stomach. Why is it happening?Hi doctor,Whenever I eat, the food gets stuck while entering the stomach. I have to drink water to flush it down. The fact that you have to throw up to breathe suggests that you are at a significant risk of choking and aspiration (where food or water gets into your lungs). The feeling of food getting stuck while it is entering your stomach is highly suggestive of an issue with your esophagus, the tube that connects your throat to your stomach. One of the most common causes of this is esophageal stricture, which is a narrowing of the esophagus. This can be caused by long-term acid reflux, an allergic reaction, or in some cases, radiation therapy. When the esophagus narrows, food has a difficult time passing through, which is why you have to drink water to flush it down. Another very strong possibility is a condition called achalasia, which is a rare disorder that makes it difficult for food and liquid to pass into the stomach. This happens when the muscles at the end of the esophagus, the lower esophageal sphincter, fail to relax. The fact that you have to throw up to breathe is also a very serious symptom that could be a sign of a buildup of food in your esophagus that is pressing on your windpipe. You should contact a doctor immediately or go to an emergency room. A gastroenterologist can perform a procedure called an endoscopy, where a small camera is inserted into your esophagus to get a direct view of the problem. This can help to determine the exact cause of your symptoms and to create a treatment plan that can help you swallow safely.

Some of the most common and effective combinations include pembrolizumab plus axitinib, nivolumab plus cabozantinib, and avelumab plus axitinib. These combinations have shown better outcomes and longer progression-free survival in many patients compared to TKIs alone. Your husband's oncologist will likely recommend a new treatment plan based on his specific cancer type, his overall health, and the side effects he has experienced. human_answers: Hello, Welcome Thanks for consulting HCM,  I have gone through your query, as you have mentioned that you have undergone extraction now you feel like dry socket , dont worry  No , you dont have Dry socket . Dry socket have pain bleeding foul smell from mouth , so dont worry you dnt have .  Do m warm saline gargle two - three times a day Take proper antibiotic course prescribed by your dentist. .Hope this will help you.
chatgpt_answers: After having an upper molar extracted, the formation of a blood clot in the socket is a crucial part of the healing process. This clot protects the underlying bone and nerve endings and is essential for the socket to heal properly. The fact that you have a new hole and no pain (yet) is a sign that you may be at risk of developing a dry socket, which is a painful condition that occurs when the blood clot is dislodged or dissolves prematurely. The chances of developing a dry socket are highest in the first three to four days after the extraction. If you do develop a dry socket, the pain will be severe and will likely radiate to your ear, neck, and temple. You may also notice a bad odor or a foul taste in your mouth. If you start to experience these symptoms, you should contact your dentist or oral surgeon immediately. A dry socket requires medical attention and cannot be treated at home. The dentist will likely clean the socket and pack it with a medicated dressing, which will help to relieve the pain and promote healing. In the meantime, you should take some preventative measures to avoid a dry socket. You should stop using the salt water rinse and avoid any actions that could dislodge the clot, such as drinking through a straw, smoking, or spitting. You should also stick to a diet of soft foods and chew on the opposite side of your mouth. Gently rinse your mouth with water after eating to keep the area clean. While the chances of a dry socket are low, it is better to be safe than sorry.

question: How can front teeth positions be corrected?hello, I am an 18 yr old male. I got my braces off 2 years back. I wore my retainers for about 10 months and then i discontinued wearing them. Now i feel that my front teeth are shifting forward from the root! What is the best way to correct them. I dont want braces again. Thanks
human_answers: Hello Read your query as you have undergone orthodontic treatment now you feel of forwadly shifting of tooth dont worry you have to wear retainer for year as it was advisved by your orthodontist , I will suggest you to consult your orthodontist again and go for oral examination and discuss about retainer . Hope this will help you.
chatgpt_answers: It is a very common and frustrating experience to see your teeth shift after your braces have been removed, especially when you have been diligent about wearing your retainers. The fact that you stopped wearing them after 10 months is the most likely cause of your teeth shifting, as your teeth have a natural memory and will try to shift back to their original position if they are not held in place. The feeling that your front teeth are shifting forward from the root is a common way to describe this phenomenon. The good news is that you do not necessarily need to go back to traditional braces. Given that your teeth have only been shifting for about a year and a half, the movement is likely not as severe as it would be if you had never had braces. The best option for you is to go back to your orthodontist or a new one for an evaluation. They can assess the current position of your teeth and recommend a new treatment plan. The most common and effective alternative to braces for this type of relapse is clear aligners, such as Invisalign. These are a series of custom-made, clear trays that you wear for about 22 hours a day. They are virtually invisible and can gently move your teeth back into their correct position. The treatment time is often much shorter than with traditional braces, and since your teeth have already been straightened once, the process should be more straightforward. Another option could be a new set of retainers. If the shifting is minimal, a new retainer may be able to correct the issue without the need for a full set of aligners. A new retainer can be made to fit your current tooth position, and if you wear it consistently as prescribed, it can prevent any further shifting.

These symptoms—excessive thirst, frequent urination, and lethargy—are classic signs of Type 1 diabetes in a child. This is a very serious medical condition that needs to be diagnosed and treated with insulin immediately. Given the combination of these symptoms, you should not wait. You should make an appointment with her GP as soon as possible. They can perform a physical examination and may order tests, such as a urinalysis and a blood test, to determine the exact cause of her symptoms. In the meantime, you should continue to give her plenty of fluids and make sure she is not getting dehydrated.

Buprenorphine, while a valuable medication, can have significant side effects, especially when misused. First, to answer your question about its classification: buprenorphine is a synthetic opioid. While this makes it a safer option for treating opioid use disorder, it can still cause dangerous side effects, particularly when not taken as prescribed. chatgpt_answers: The symptoms you've described—a persistent need to keep your house spotless, a rigid need for everything to have a specific place, and the anxiety that arises when things are out of order—are classic signs of Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD). While many people have an affinity for cleanliness, in OCD, these behaviors are characterized by the presence of both obsessions and compulsions. The obsessions are the intrusive, unwanted thoughts or fears (e.g., the house is not clean, things are out of place), and the compulsions are the repetitive behaviors (e.g., cleaning, organizing) you perform to neutralize or reduce the anxiety caused by the obsessions. The fact that you feel compelled to put things back immediately and get anxious when they're not is a strong indicator of this. The good news is that OCD is a very treatable condition. The most effective treatment for OCD is a combination of psychotherapy and medication. One of the most common and effective forms of therapy for OCD is Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), specifically a technique called Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP). ERP involves gradually exposing you to your fears or obsessions (e.g., having something out of place) and then teaching you to resist the urge to perform the compulsive behavior (e.g., not putting it back immediately). Over time, this helps to break the cycle of anxiety and compulsion. In some cases, a doctor may also prescribe medication, such as an antidepressant or a Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor (SSRI), to help manage the anxiety and obsessive thoughts.
